{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{short description|low "effective" tax rates for foreigners}} {{see also|Offshore financial centre|Corporate tax haven}} {{Taxation}} A '''tax haven''' is generally defined as a country or place with very low "effective" rates of taxation for foreigners ("headline" rates may be higher{{efn|Many corporate–focused tax havens have high nominal rates of taxation (e.g. Netherlands at 25%, United Kingdom at 19%, Singapore at 17%, and Ireland at 12.5%), but maintain a tax ''regime'' that excludes sufficient items from taxable income to bring the ''effective'' rates of taxation closer to zero}}).<ref name="ftlex">{{cite web|url = http://lexicon.ft.com/Term?term=tax-haven|title=Financial Times Lexicon: Definition of tax haven:|quote=A country with little or no taxation that offers foreign individuals or corporations residency so that they can avoid tax at home.|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Collins">{{cite web|title=Tax haven definition and meaning {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|quote=A tax haven is a country or place which has a low rate of tax so that people choose to live there or register companies there in order to avoid paying higher tax in their own countries.|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/tax-haven|publisher=Collins Dictionary|accessdate=27 December 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Cambridge">{{cite web|title=Tax haven definition and meaning {{!}} Cambridge English Dictionary |quote=a place where people pay less tax than they would pay if they lived in their own country|url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/tax-haven|publisher=Cambridge English Dictionary|date=2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name="dhar">{{cite journal|author1=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|author2=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|page=1058-1068|quote=The “tax havens” are locations with very low tax rates and other tax attributes designed to appeal to foreign investors. | url=http://faculty.smu.edu/millimet/classes/eco6375/papers/dharmapala%20hines.pdf | title=Which countries become tax havens?|journal=[[Journal of Public Economics]]|date=2009|volume=93|issue=9-10}}</ref><ref name="hines2016">{{cite journal| url =https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2831&context=articles|title=Multinational Firms and Tax Havens|author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Anna Gumpert|author3=Monika Schnitzer|date=2016|journal=[[The Review of Economics and Statistics]]|page=713-727|quote=Tax havens are typically small, well-governed states that impose low or zero tax rates on foreign investors.|volume=98|issue=4}}</ref> In some traditional definitions, a tax haven also offers financial secrecy.{{efn|Since the post–2000 OECD–IMF–FATF initiatives on reducing banking secrecy and increasing transparency, modern academics consider the ''secrecy'' component to be redundant. See {{slink|#Definitions}}.}}<ref name="Explainer">{{cite news|last1=Shaxson|first1=Nicholas|title=Explainer: what is a tax haven?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/jan/09/explainer-what-is-tax-haven|accessdate=27 December 2017|work=The Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|date=9 January 2011}}</ref> However, while countries with high levels of secrecy but also high rates of taxation (e.g. the United States and Germany in the [[Financial Secrecy Index]] ("FSI") rankings),{{efn|name=FSI|The FSI is often misquoted as a ranking of "tax havens", however the FSI does not quantify tax avoidance or BEPS flows like modern quantitative tax haven lists; the FSI it is a qualitative scoring of ''secrecy indicators'', and does not score some of the most common secrecy tools - the [[unlimited liability company]], the trust, and various special purpose vehicles (e.g. Irish QIAIFs and L–QIAIFs) - few of which are required to file public accounts in major tax havens, such as Ireland and the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2018/06/25/new-report-is-apple-paying-less-than-1-tax-in-the-eu/|title=New report: is Apple paying less than 1% tax in the EU?|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=28 June 2018|quote=The use of private "unlimited liability company" (ULC) status, which exempts companies from filing financial reports publicly. The fact that Apple, Google and many others continue to keep their Irish financial information secret is due to a failure by the Irish government to implement the 2013 EU Accounting Directive, which would require full public financial statements, until 2017, and even then retaining an exemption from financial reporting for certain holding companies until 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taxresearch.org.uk/Blog/2018/07/04/irelands-playing-games-in-the-last-chance-saloon-of-tax-justice/|title=Ireland's playing games in the last chance saloon of tax justice|publisher=[[Richard Murphy (tax campaigner)|Richard Murphy]]|date=4 July 2018|quote=Local subsidiaries of multinationals must always be required to file their accounts on public record, which is not the case at present. Ireland is not just a tax haven at present, it is also a corporate secrecy jurisdiction.}}</ref>}} can feature in some tax haven lists, they are not universally considered as tax havens. In contrast, countries with lower levels of secrecy but also low "effective" rates of taxation (e.g. Ireland in the [[Financial Secrecy Index|FSI]] rankings), appear in most {{slink|#Tax haven lists}}.<ref name="TJN1">{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/cms/upload/pdf/Identifying_Tax_Havens_Jul_07.pdf|title=Identifying Tax Havens and Offshore Finance Centres|quote=Various attempts have been made to identify and list tax havens and offshore finance centres (OFCs). This Briefing Paper aims to compare these lists and clarify the criteria used in preparing them.|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]] and [[Centre for Research on Multinational Corporations]]|date=July 2007|author1=Laurens Booijink|author2=Francis Weyzig}}</ref> The consensus around ''effective tax rates'' has led academics to note that the term "tax haven" and "[[offshore financial centre]]" are almost synonymous.<ref name="missing profits">{{cite journal| url= https://eml.berkeley.edu/~saez/course/zucman11.pdf|title=The Missing Wealth of Nations: Are Europe and The U.S. Net Debtors or Net Creditors?|author=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|journal=[[The Quarterly Journal of Economics]]|volume=128|issue=3|page=1321-1364|date=August 2013|quote=Tax havens are low-tax jurisdictions that offer businesses and individuals opportunities for tax avoidance” (Hines, 2008). In this paper, I will use the expression “tax haven” and “offshore financial center” interchangeably (the list of tax havens considered by Dharmapala and Hines (2009) is identical to the list of offshore financial centers considered by the Financial Stability Forum (IMF, 2000), barring minor exceptions)}}</ref>
Traditional tax havens, like Jersey, are open about zero rates of taxation, but as a consequence have limited bilateral [[tax treaty|tax treaties]]. Modern [[corporate tax haven]]s have non-zero "headline" rates of taxation and high levels of [[OECD]]–compliance, and thus have large networks of bilateral [[Tax treaty|tax treaties]]. However, their [[base erosion and profit shifting]] ("BEPS") tools enable corporates to achieve "effective" tax rates closer to zero, not just in the haven but in all countries with which the haven has tax treaties; putting them on tax haven lists. According to modern studies, the {{slink|#Top 10 tax havens}} include corporate-focused havens like Ireland, the Netherlands, Singapore, and the U.K., while Switzerland, Luxembourg, Hong Kong, and the Caribbean (the Caymans, Bermuda, and the British Virgin Islands), feature as both major traditional tax havens and major corporate tax havens. Corporate tax havens often serve as [[Conduit and Sink OFCs|"conduits"]] to traditional tax havens.<ref name="guar">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/25/netherlands-and-uk-are-biggest-channels-for-corporate-tax-avoidance|title=Netherlands and UK are biggest channels for corporate tax avoidance|publisher=The Guardian|date=25 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="bloom">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-31/is-the-u-k-already-the-kind-of-tax-haven-it-claims-it-won-t-be|title=Is the U.K. Already the Kind of Tax Haven It Claims It Won't Be?|publisher=Bloomberg News|date=31 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="bloom2">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-04-11/tax-havens-can-be-surprisingly-close-to-home|title=Tax Havens Can Be Surprisingly Close to Home|publisher=Bloomberg View|date=11 April 2017}}</ref>
Use of tax havens, traditional and corporate, results in a loss of tax revenues to countries which are not tax havens. Estimates of total amounts of taxes avoided vary, but the most credible have a range of US$100–250 billion per annum.<ref name="zucwsj">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=Such profit shifting leads to a total annual revenue loss of $250 billion globally|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="gzuc"/><ref name="BEPS Background"/> In addition, capital held in tax havens can permanently leave the tax base (base erosion). Estimates of capital held in tax havens also vary: the most credible estimates are between $7–10 trillion (up to 10% of global assets).<ref name=Zucman/> The harm of traditional and corporate tax havens has been particularly noted in developing nations, where the tax revenues are needed to build infrastructure.<ref name="zucc"/>
At least 15%{{efn|name=number|The [[list of sovereign states]] numbered 206 as at September 2018, so 15% equates to just over 30 tax havens; the OECD's 2000 list had 35 tax havens,<ref name="OECDh"/> the [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines 2010 list|James Hines 2010 list]] had 52 tax havens<ref name="h1"/>, the 2017 [[Conduit and Sink OFCs]] study lists 29 states.}} of countries are tax havens.<ref name="dhar"/><ref name="TJN1"/> Tax havens are mostly successful and well-governed economies, and being a haven has often brought prosperity.<ref name="h2">{{cite web|url=http://www.bus.umich.edu/otpr/WP2007-3.pdf|title=Tax Havens|quote=Tax havens are low-tax jurisdictions that offer businesses and individuals opportunities for tax avoidance. They attract disproportionate shares of world foreign direct investment, and, largely as a consequence, their economies have grown much more rapidly than the world as a whole over the past 25 years.|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|publisher=[[The New Palgrave Dictionary of Economics]]|date=2007}}</ref><ref name="mich"/> The top 10–15 [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita|GDP-per-capita]] countries, excluding oil and gas exporters, are tax havens. Because of {{slink|#Inflated GDP-per-capita}} (due to accounting BEPS flows), havens are prone to over-leverage (international capital misprice the artificial debt-to-GDP). This can lead to severe credit cycles and/or property/banking crises when international capital flows are repriced. Ireland's [[Celtic Tiger]], and the subsequent financial crisis in 2009–13, is an example.<ref name="ber"/> [[Jersey]] is another.<ref name="jersey">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/08/fall-of-jersey-how-tax-haven-goes-bust|title=The fall of Jersey: how a tax haven goes bust|publisher=The Guardian|author=Oliver Bullough|quote=Jersey bet its future on finance but since 2007 it has fallen on hard times and is heading for bankruptcy. Is the island's perilous present Britain's bleak future?|date=8 December 2015}}</ref> Research shows the {{slink|#U.S. as the largest beneficiary}}, and U.S. multinational use of tax havens, has maximised long-term U.S. exchequer receipts;<ref name="dryng"/> however experts note OECD jurisdictions accommodated the U.S. to overcome shortcomings in the U.S. "worldwide" tax system (others use "territorial" systems, and don't need havens).
The focus on combating tax havens (e.g. OECD–[[IMF]] projects) has been on common standards, transparency and data sharing.<ref name="crs2"/> The rise of OECD-compliant corporate tax havens, whose BEPS tools are responsible for most of the quantum of lost taxes,<ref name="BEPS Background">{{cite web|title=BEPS Project Background Brief| url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/background-brief-inclusive-framework-for-beps-implementation.pdf|publisher=[[OECD]]|quote=With a conservatively estimated annual revenue loss of USD 100 to 240 billion, the stakes are high for governments around the world. The impact of BEPS on developing countries, as a percentage of tax revenues, is estimated to be even higher than in developed countries.|date=January 2017|page=9}}</ref> has led to criticism of this focus, versus actual taxes paid.<ref name="un1">{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/09/11/new-un-tax-handbook-sets-lower-income-countries-oecd-beps/|title=New UN tax handbook: Lower-income countries vs OECD BEPS failure|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|author= Alex Cobham| date=11 September 2017}}</ref> Higher-tax jurisdictions, such as the United States and many member states of the European Union, departed from the [[Base erosion and profit shifting (OECD project)|OCED BEPS Project]] in 2017–18, to introduce anti-BEPS tax regimes, targeted raising net taxes paid by corporations in corporate tax havens (e.g. the U.S. [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] ("TCJA") GILTI–BEAT–FDII tax regimes and move to a hybrid "territorial" tax system, and the proposed EU Digital Services Tax regime and the proposed EU [[Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base]]).
==Definitions== [[File:James R. Hines Jr. C-SPAN.jpg|thumb|[[James R. Hines Jr.]] testifying to the Senate Finance Committee on Corporate Taxation in 2016. Hines is the most cited academic on research into tax havens;<ref name="respec"/> and his [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines-Rice paper|1994 Hines–Rice paper]], the most cited paper in all tax haven research,<ref name="respec"/> was relied upon by the [[Council of Economic Advisors]] in October 2017 when advocating the corporate tax cuts proposed by the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|Tax Cuts and Jobs Act]].<ref name="CRS2"/>{{efn|name=CEA|The final report by tbe Council of Economic Advisors on the economic theory underpinning the TCJA, also used other tax papers from Hines, and also referenced Mihir A. Deasi and Dhammika Dharmapala's work, two of Hines' co-authors in tax haven research}}]]
The consensus regarding a specific and exact definition of what constitutes a tax haven, is that there is none. This is the conclusion from [[non-governmental organisations]], such as the [[Tax Justice Network]],<ref name="tjn10">{{cite web | url=https://www.taxjustice.net/faq/tax-havens/|title=Tax Havens|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|quote=There is no generally agreed definition of what a tax haven is. |date=2018}}</ref> from the 2008 investigation by the U.S. [[Government Accountability Office]],<ref name="congress1">{{cite web|url=https://www.gao.gov/assets/290/284522.pdf|title=INTERNATIONAL TAXATION: Large U.S. Corporations and Federal Contractors with Subsidiaries in Jurisdictions Listed as Tax Havens or Financial Privacy Jurisdictions|publisher=[[Government Accountability Office]]|quote=Table 1: Jurisdictions Listed as Tax Havens or Financial Privacy Jurisdictions and the Sources of Those Jurisdictions | page=12 | date=18 December 2008}}</ref> from the 2015 investigation by the U.S. [[Congressional Research Service]],<ref name="CRS">{{cite web|url=https://digitalcommons.ilr.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2387&context=key_workplace|title=Tax Havens: International Tax Avoidance and Evasion |author=Jane Gravelle|publisher=[[Congressional Research Service]], [[Cornell University]] | page=4 |quote=Table 1. Countries Listed on Various Tax Haven Lists | date=15 January 2015}}</ref> from the 2017 investigation by the European Parliament,<ref name="EUP">{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2017/614633/EPRS_BRI(2017)614633_EN.pdf|title=Understanding the rationale for compiling 'tax haven' lists|publisher=[[European Parliamentary Research Service]]|page=3|quote=There is no single definition of a tax haven, although there are a number of commonalities in the various concepts used|date=December 2017}}</ref> and from leading academic researchers of tax havens.<ref name="dhh">{{cite journal| url=https://academic.oup.com/oxrep/article/24/4/661/547359#|title=What Problems and Opportunities are Created by Tax Havens?|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|journal=[[Oxford Review of Economic Policy]]|page=3|quote=Although tax havens have attracted widespread interest (and a considerable amount of opprobrium) in recent years, there is no standard definition of what this term means. Typically, the term is applied to countries and territories that offer favorable tax regimes for foreign investors.|date=December 2008|volume=24|issue=4}}</ref>
The issue, however, is material, as being labelled a "tax haven" has consequences for a country seeking to develop and trade under bilateral tax treaties. When Ireland was "blacklisted" by G20 member Brazil in 2016, bilateral trade declined.<ref name="reuters1">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ireland-brazil-funds/blacklisted-by-brazil-dublin-funds-find-new-ways-to-invest-idUSL8N1MK2NX|title=Blacklisted by Brazil, Dublin funds find new ways to invest|publisher=Reuters|date=20 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/04/10/tax-haven-blacklisting-13-latin-american-countries/|title=Tax haven blacklisting in Latin America|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=6 April 2017}}</ref> It is even more onerous for corporate tax havens, whose foreign multinationals rely on the haven's extensive network of bilateral [[tax treaties]], through which the foreign multinationals execute BEPS transactions, re-routing global untaxed income to the haven.
One of the first {{slink|#Important papers on tax havens}},<ref name="eup">{{cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/info/files/dp_055_en.pdf|title=Banks in Tax Havens: First Evidence based on Country-by-Country Reporting|page=50|author1=Vincent Bouvatier|author2=Gunther Capelle-Blancard |author3=Anne-Laure Delatte| quote=Figure D: Tax Haven Literature Review: A Typology|publisher=[[EU Commission]]|date=July 2017}}</ref> was the 1994 [[James R. Hines Jr.#Tax haven research|Hines–Rice paper]] by [[James R. Hines Jr.]]<ref name="h3">{{cite journal|url=http://taxdoctoralseminar.web.unc.edu/files/2016/02/Hines-Rice.pdf|title=FISCAL PARADISE: FOREIGN TAX HAVENS AND AMERICAN BUSINESS |author1=James R. Hines Jr.|author2=Eric Rice|quote=We identify 41 countries and regions as tax havens for the purposes of U. S. businesses. Together the seven tax havens with populations greater than one million (Hong Kong, Ireland, Liberia, Lebanon, Panama, Singapore, and Switzerland) account for 80 percent of total tax haven population and 89 percent of tax haven GDP. |journal=[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]] (Harvard/MIT)|date=February 1994|volume=9|issue=1}}</ref> It is the most cited paper on tax haven research,<ref name="respec"/> even in late 2017,<ref name="CRS2">{{cite web| url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/documents/Tax%20Reform%20and%20Wages.pdf|publisher=[[Council of Economic Advisors]]|title=TAX CUTS AND JOBS ACT OF 2017 Corporate Tax Reform and Wages: Theory and Evidence|quote=[In the Whitehouse advocating for the TCJA] Applying Hines and Rice’s (1994) findings to a statutory corporate rate reduction of 15 percentage points (from 35 to 20 percent) suggests that reduced profit shifting would result in more than $140 billion of repatriated profit based on 2016 numbers.|date=17 October 2017}}</ref> and Hines is the most cited author on tax haven research.<ref name="respec">{{cite web|url=https://ideas.repec.org/cgi-bin/htsearch?form=extended&wm=wrd&dt=range&ul=&q=tax+haven&cmd=Search%21&wf=4BFF&s=C&db=&de=|title=IDEAS/RePEc Database|quote=Tax Havens by Most Cited}}</ref> As well as offering insights into tax havens, it took the view that the diversity of countries that become tax havens was so great that detailed definitions were inappropriate. Hines merely noted that tax havens were: ''a group of countries with unusually low tax rates''. Hines reaffirmed this approach in a 2009 paper with [[Dhammika Dharmapala]].<ref name="dhar"/> He refined it in 2016 to incorporate research on {{slink|#Incentives for tax havens}} on governance, which is broadly accepted in the academic lexicon.<ref name="missing profits"/><ref name="cesifo">{{cite journal|url=http://www.cesifo-group.de/DocDL/cesifo1_wp7171.pdf|title=Firms, Trade and Profit Shifting: Evidence from Aggregate Data|author1=Sébastien Laffitte|author2=Farid Toubal|journal=[[CESifo Economic Studies]]|date=July 2018|quote=Concerning the characterization of tax havens, we follow the definition proposed by Hines and Rice (1994) which has been recently used by Dharmapala and Hines (2009).|page=8}}</ref><ref name="eup"/>
{{quote|Tax havens are typically small, well-governed states that impose low or zero tax rates on foreign investors.|title=[[James R. Hines Jr.]] "Multinational Firms and Tax Havens"|source=[[The Review of Economics and Statistics]] (2016)<ref name="hines2016"/>}}
In April 1998, the OECD produced a definition of a tax haven, as meeting "three of four" criteria.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.oecd.org/ctp/harmful/42469606.pdf|title=COUNTERING OFFSHORE TAX EVASION|publisher=OECD|page=3|date=September 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/document/63/0,3343,en_2649_37427_30575447_1_1_1_37427,00.html |title=Tax Haven Criteria |publisher=Oecd.org |date= 26 February 2008 |accessdate=2011-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512074208/http://www.oecd.org/document/63/0,3343,en_2649_37427_30575447_1_1_1_37427,00.html |archivedate=12 May 2012 }}</ref> It was produced as part of their "Harmful Tax Competition: An Emerging Global Issue" initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/transparency/about-the-global-forum/publications/harmful-tax-competition-emerging-global-issue.pdf|title=Harmful Tax Competition: An Emerging Global Issue|publisher=OECD|date=9 April 1998}}</ref> By 2000, when the OECD published their first list of tax havens,<ref name="OECDh">{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/ctp/harmful/2090192.pdf|title=Towards Global Tax Co-operation|date=April 2000|page=17|publisher=[[OECD]]|quote=TAX HAVENS: 1.Andorra 2.Anguilla 3.Antigua and Barbuda 4.Aruba 5.Bahamas 6.Bahrain 7.Barbados 8.Belize 9.British Virgin Islands 10.Cook Islands 11.Dominica 12.Gibraltar 13.Grenada 14.Guernsey 15.Isle of Man 16.Jersey 17.Liberia 18.Liechtenstein 19.Maldives 20.Marshall Islands 21.Monaco 22.Montserrat 23.Nauru 24.Net Antilles 25.Niue 26.Panama 27.Samoa 28.Seychelles 29.St. Lucia 30.St. Kitts & Nevis 31.St. Vincent and the Grenadines 32.Tonga 33.Turks & Caicos 34.U.S. Virgin Islands 35.Vanuatu}}</ref> it included no OECD member countries as they were now all considered to have engaged in the OECD's new [[Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes]], and therefore would not meet ''Criteria ii'' and ''Criteria iii''. Because the [[OECD]] has never listed any of its 35 members as tax havens, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Switzerland are sometimes defined as the "OECD tax havens".<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://francisweyzig.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/weyzig-tax-treaty-shopping-20120810.pdf|title=Tax treaty shopping: structural determinants of FDI routed through the Netherlands|quote=The four OECD member countries Luxembourg, Ireland, Belgium and Switzerland, which can also be regarded as tax havens for multinationals because of their special tax regimes.|journal=''International Tax and Public Finance''|author=Francis Weyzig|date=2013|volume=20|issue=6|page=910-937}}</ref> In 2017, only Trinidad & Tobago met the 1998 OECD definition, and it has fallen into disrepute.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.ft.com/content/94d84054-5bf0-11e7-b553-e2df1b0c3220|title=Trinidad & Tobago left as the last blacklisted tax haven|publisher=Financial Times|quote=Alex Cobham of the [[Tax Justice Network]] said: It’s disheartening to see the OECD fall back into the old pattern of creating ‘tax haven’ blacklists on the basis of criteria that are so weak as to be near enough meaningless, and then declaring success when the list is empty.” |date=September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.humanosphere.org/world-politics/2017/06/activists-and-experts-ridicule-oecds-tax-havens-blacklist-as-a-farce/|title=Activists and experts ridicule OECD’s tax havens ‘blacklist’ as a farce|publisher=Humanosphere|quote=One of the criteria, for example, is that a country must be at least “largely compliant” with the Exchange Of Information on Request standard, a bilateral country-to-country information exchange. According to Turner, this standard is outdated and has been proven to not really work.|date=30 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.oxfam.org.nz/news/oxfam-disputes-opaque-oecd-failing-just-one-tax-haven-transparency|title=Oxfam disputes opaque OECD failing just one tax haven on transparency|publisher=Oxfam|date=30 June 2017}}</ref>
{{ordered list|type=lower-roman |No or nominal tax on the relevant income; |Lack of effective exchange of information; |Lack of transparency; |''No substantial activities (e.g. tolerance of [[brass plate company|brass plate companies]])''.† }}
(†) The 4th criterion was withdrawn after objections from the new U.S. Bush Administration in 2001,<ref name="crs2">{{cite web|url=https://info.publicintelligence.net/R40114.pdf|title=The OECD Initiative on Tax Havens|date=11 March 2010|publisher=[[Congressional Research Service]]|author=James K. Jackson|page=7|quote=As a result of the Bush Administration’s efforts, the OECD backed away from its efforts to target “harmful tax practices” and shifted the scope of its efforts to improving exchanges of tax information between member countries.}}</ref> and in the OECD's 2002 report the definition became "two of three criteria".<ref name="TJN1"/>
The 1998 OECD definition is most frequently invoked by the "OECD tax havens".<ref name="esri">{{cite web | url=https://igees.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/What-makes-a-country-a-tax-haven.pdf|title=What Makes a Country a Tax Haven? An Assessment of International Standards Shows Why Ireland Is Not a Tax Haven|publisher=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]/[[Economic and Social Research Institute]] Review|page=403|date=September 2013|quote= Ireland does not meet any of the OECD criteria for being a tax haven but because of its 12.5 per cent corporation tax rate and the open nature of the Irish economy, Ireland has on a few occasions been labelled a tax haven.}}</ref> However, it has been discounted by tax haven academics,<ref name="dhh"/><ref name="cesifo"/><ref name="ronen.palan">{{cite web|url=http://www.historyandpolicy.org/policy-papers/papers/history-of-tax-havens|title=History of Tax Havens|author=[[Ronen Palan]]|quote=The OECD is clearly ill-equipped to deal with tax havens, not least as many of its members, including the UK, Switzerland, Ireland and the Benelux countries are themselves considered tax havens |publisher=History and Policy|date=1 October 2009}}</ref> including the 2015 U.S. [[Congressional Research Service]] investigation into tax havens, as being restrictive, and enabling Hines’ low-tax havens (e.g. to which the first criterion applies), to avoid the OECD definition by improving OECD corporation (so the second and third criteria do not apply).<ref name="CRS"/>
{{quote|Thus, the evidence (limited though it undoubtedly is) does not suggest any impact of the OECD initiative on tax-haven activity. [..] Thus, the OECD initiative cannot be expected to have much impact on corporate uses of tax havens, even if (or when) the initiative is fully implemented|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|source="What Problems and Opportunities are created by Tax Havens?" (December 2008)<ref name="dhh"/>}}
In April 2000, the [[Financial Stability Forum]] (or FSF) defined the related concept of an [[offshore financial centre]] (or OFC),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/r_0004b.pdf?page_moved=1|title=Report from the Working Group on Offshore Centres|publisher=[[Financial Stability Forum]]|date=5 April 2000}}</ref> which the IMF adopted in June 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imf.org/external/np/mae/oshore/2000/eng/back.htm|title=Offshore Financial Centers: IMF Background Paper|publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]]|date=23 June 2000}}</ref> An OFC is similar to a "tax haven" and the terms are sometimes used interchangeably, but the term OFC is less controversial and pejorative.<ref name="missing profits"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.academic-foresights.com/Tax_Havens.pdf|quote=Some experts see no difference between tax havens and OFCs and employ the terms interchangeably. |title=Tax Havens and Offshore Financial Centres|publisher=University of Birmingham|author=[[Ronen Palan]]|date=4 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="ronen">{{cite web|url=http://www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/?GCOI=80140100541250|page=24|quote=Yet today it is difficult to distinguish between the activities of tax havens and OFCs.| title=Tax Havens and Offshore Financial Centres|publisher=Cornell University Press|author=[[Ronen Palan]]|author2=[[Richard Murphy (tax campaigner)|Richard Murphy]]|date=2010}}</ref> The FSF–IMF definition focused on the [[BEPS]] tools havens offer, and on [[James R. Hines Jr.|Hines]]' observation that the accounting flows from BEPS tools distort the economic statistics of the haven. The FSF–IMF list captured new [[corporate tax havens]], such as the Netherlands, which Hines considered too small in 1994.<ref name="TJN1"/>
In December 2008, Dharmapala wrote that the OECD process had removed much of the need to include "bank secrecy" in any definition of a tax haven and that it was now "first and foremost, low or zero corporate tax rates",<ref name="dhh"/> and this has become the general "financial dictionary" definition of a tax haven.<ref name="ftlex"/><ref name="Collins"/><ref name="Cambridge"/>
In October 2009, the [[Tax Justice Network]] introduced the [[Financial Secrecy Index]] ("FSI") and the term "secrecy jurisdiction",<ref name="tjn10"/> to highlight issues in regard to OECD-compliant countries who have high tax rates and do not appear on academic lists of tax havens, but have transparency issues. The FSI does not assess tax rates or BEPS flows in its calculation; but it is often misinterpreted as a tax haven definition in the financial media,{{efn|name=FSI}} particularly when it lists the USA and Germany as major "secrecy jurisdictions".<ref name="Drucker2016"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Wood|first=Robert W.|title=The World's Next Top Tax Haven Is...America|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertwood/2016/01/27/the-worlds-next-top-tax-haven-is-america|accessdate=7 June 2016|work=Forbes|date=27 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Swanson|first=Ana|title=How the U.S. became one of the world's biggest tax havens|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/04/05/how-the-u-s-became-one-of-the-worlds-biggest-tax-havens/|accessdate=23 April 2016|work=Washington Post|date=5 April 2016}}</ref> However, many types of tax havens also rank as secrecy jurisdictions.
In October 2010, Hines published a list of [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines 2010 list|52 tax havens]], scaled by analysing corporate investment flows.<ref name="h1">{{cite journal|url=https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.ie/&httpsredir=1&article=1716&context=articles|title=Treasure Islands|page=103-125|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|quote=Table 1: 52 Tax Havens|journal=[[Journal of Economic Perspectives]]|volume=4|issue=24|date=2010}}</ref> Hines' largest havens were dominated by corporate tax havens, who Dharmapala noted in 2014 accounted for the bulk of global tax haven activity from BEPS tools.<ref name="be">{{cite web|url=https://chicagounbound.uchicago.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2385&context=law_and_economics|title=What Do We Know About Base Erosion and Profit Shifting? A Review of the Empirical Literature|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|date=2014|quote= It focuses particularly on the dominant approach within the economics literature on income shifting, which dates back to Hines and Rice (1994) and which we refer to as the “Hines-Rice” approach.|page=1}}</ref> The Hines 2010 list was the first to estimate the ten largest global tax havens, only two of which, Jersey and the British Virgin Isles, were on the OECD’s 2000 list.
In July 2017, the [[University of Amsterdam]]'s CORPNET group ignored any definition of a tax haven and focused on a purely quantitive approach, analysing 98 million global corporate connections on the [[Bureau van Dijk|Orbis database]]. CORPNET's lists of top five [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFCs]], and top five [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFCs]], matched 9 of the top 10 havens in Hines' 2010 list, only differing in the United Kingdom, which only [[Corporate haven#U.K. transformation|transformed their tax code in 2009–12]]. CORPNET's [[Conduit and Sink OFCs]] study split the understanding of a tax haven into two classifications:<ref name="xx">{{cite journal |author1=Javier Garcia-Bernardo|author2=Jan Fichtner|author3=Frank W. Takes|author4=Eelke M. Heemskerk | url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-06322-9 | volume=7 | issue=6246 | title=Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers: Conduits and Sinks in the Global Corporate Ownership Network | journal=[[Scientific Reports]], [[Nature Publishing Group]] | date=24 July 2017}}</ref>
* 24 Sink OFCs: jurisdictions in which a disproportionate amount of value disappears from the economic system (e.g. the traditional [[tax havens]]). * 5 Conduit OFCs: jurisdictions through which a disproportionate amount of value moves toward sink OFCs (e.g. the modern [[corporate tax haven]]s).
In June 2018, tax academic [[Gabriel Zucman]] (''et alia'') published research that also ignored any definition of a tax haven, but estimated the corporate "profit shifting" (i.e. [[BEPS]]), and "enhanced corporate profitability" that Hines and Dharmapala had noted.<ref name="gbz">{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/missingprofits/|title=The Missing Profits of Nations|quote=Appendix Table 2: Tax Havens|page=31|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Torslov|author3=Ludvig Wier|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|date=June 2018}}</ref> Zucman pointed out that the CORPNET research under-represented havens associated with US technology firms, like Ireland and the [[Cayman Islands]], as Google, Facebook and Apple do not appear on Orbis.<ref name="zucz">{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/TWZ2018Slides.pdf|page=35|title=The Missing Profits of Nations|author=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers| date=April 2018}}</ref> Even so, Zucman's 2018 list of top 10 havens also matched 9 of the top 10 havens in Hines' 2010 list, but with Ireland as the largest global haven.<ref name="zux">{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401|title=Ireland is the world’s biggest corporate ‘tax haven’, say academics|quote=New Gabriel Zucman study claims State shelters more multinational profits than the entire Caribbean|publisher=Irish Times|date=13 June 2018}}</ref> These lists (Hines 2010, CORPNET 2017 and Zucman 2018), and others, which followed a purely quantitive approach, showed a firm consensus around the largest corporate tax havens.
==Tax haven lists== {{See also|Offshore financial centre#Offshore Financial Centre lists|Corporate haven#Corporate tax haven lists}}
===Types of lists===
Three main types of tax haven lists have been produced to date:<ref name="CRS"/>
{{ordered list|type=lower-roman | Governmental, Qualitative: these lists are qualitative and political;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2018/07/27/blacklist-whitewashed-how-the-oecd-bent-its-rules-to-help-tax-haven-usa/|title=Blacklist, whitewashed: How the OECD bent its rules to help tax haven USA|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|author=Andres Knobel|quote=We’ve criticised for years the farcical nature of ‘tax haven’ blacklists, whether EU or OECD ones. They all turn out to be politicised, misleading and ineffective|date=27 July 2018}}</ref> they never list members (or each other), and are largely disregarded by academic research;<ref name="dhh"/><ref name="ronen.palan"/> the OECD had one country on its 2017 list, Trinidad & Tobago; the EU had 17 countries on its 2017 list,<ref name="eu havens">{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c4d721dc-d9cf-11e7-a039-c64b1c09b482|title=EU puts 17 countries on blacklist|publisher=Financial Times|date=5 December 2017|quote=The 17 countries on the European list are American Samoa, Bahrain, Barbados, Grenada, Guam, South Korea, Macau, the Marshall Islands, Mongolia, Namibia, Palau, Panama, St Lucia, Samoa, Trinidad & Tobago, Tunisia and the UAE}}</ref> none of which were OECD or EU countries, or {{slink|#Top 10 tax havens}}.<ref name="ced">{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/outbreak-of-so-whatery-over-eu-tax-haven-blacklist-1.3318149|title=Outbreak of ‘so whatery’ over EU tax haven blacklist|publisher=Irish Times|quote=It was certainly an improvement on the list recently published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which featured only one name – Trinidad & Tobago – but campaigners believe the European Union has much more to do if it is to prove it is serious about addressing tax havens.|date=7 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c4d721dc-d9cf-11e7-a039-c64b1c09b482|title=EU puts 17 countries on tax haven blacklist|quote=EU members were not screened but Oxfam said that if the criteria were applied to publicly available information the list should feature 35 countries including EU members Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Malta | publisher = Financial Times|date=8 December 2017}}</ref> | Non–governmental, Qualitative: these follow a subjective scoring system based on various attributes (e.g. type of tax structures available in the haven); the best known are [[Oxfam]]'s ''Corporate Tax Havens'' list,<ref name="Oxfam">{{cite web|url=https://www.oxfam.org/en/research/tax-battles-dangerous-global-race-bottom-corporate-tax | title=Tax Battles: the dangerous global race to the bottom on corporate tax | publisher=Oxfam|date=December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://d1tn3vj7xz9fdh.cloudfront.net/s3fs-public/bp-race-to-bottom-corporate-tax-121216-en.pdf | title=TAX BATTLES The dangerous global Race to the Bottom on Corporate Tax | publisher=Oxfam|date=December 2016}}</ref> and the [[Financial Secrecy Index]] (although the FSI is a list of "financial secrecy jurisdictions", and not specifically tax havens).{{efn|name=FSI}} | Non–governmental, Quantitative: by following an objective quantitative approach, they can rank the relative scale of individual havens; the best known are: * Tax rate – focus on ''effective tax rates'', like the [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines-Rice 1994 list|Hines–Rice 1994 list]],<ref name="h3"/> and the [[Dhammika Dharmapala#Dharmapala-Hines 2009 list|Dharmapala–Hines 2009 list]].<ref name="dhar"/> (Hines and Dharmapala avoided ''rankings'' in these lists). * Connections – focus on ''legal connections'', either [[Bureau van Dijk|Orbis connections]] like CORPNET's 2017 [[Conduit and Sink OFCs]], or subsidiary connections like the [[Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy#ITEP 2017 tax haven list (by quantum of connections)|ITEP Connections 2017 list]].<ref name="ITEP"/> * Quantum – focus on ''profits shifted'', either [[BEPS]] flows like the [[Gabriel Zucman#Zucman-Tørsløv-Wier 2018 list|Zucman–Tørsløv–Wier 2018 list]],<ref name="gbz"/><ref name="zuc10">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=The new research draws on data from countries such as Ireland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands that hadn’t previously been collected.|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}}</ref> [[Foreign direct investment|FDI]] flows like the [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines 2010 list|James Hines 2010 list]],<ref name="h1"/> or Profits like the [[Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy#ITEP 2017 tax haven list (by quantum of profits)|ITEP Profits 2017 list]].{{efn|name=ITEP|The ITEP list only focuses on Fortune 500 Companies; its strong correlation with tax haven lists derived from global studies highlights that U.S multinationals are the most dominant source of global tax avoidance, and users of tax havens.}}<ref name="ITEP">{{cite web|url=https://itep.org/wp-content/uploads/offshoreshellgames2017.pdf|title=Offshore Shell Games 2017|quote=Amount of Tax Haven Connections (Figure 1, Page 11), Amount of Tax Haven Profits (Figure 4, Page 16)|author1=Richard Phillips|author2=Matt Gardner|author3=Alexandria Robins|author4=Michelle Surka|publisher=[[Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy]]|date=2017}}</ref> }}
Research also highlights [[Corporate haven#Proxy tests|proxy indicators]], of which the two most prominent are: {{ordered list|type=lower-roman | U.S. [[tax inversion]]s – A basic "sense-check" of a tax haven is whether individuals or corporates relocate there to avoid taxes (i.e. why accusations of the U.S. as a tax haven are not considered credible). While individual relocations are hard to track, corporations are easier. The top 3 destinations for all U.S. corporate [[tax inversion]]s since 1982 are: Ireland (#1), Bermuda (#2) and the U.K. (#3);<ref name="bbb"/> | [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita|GDP-per-capita]] tables – Another effective "sense–check" of a tax haven is distortion in its GDP/GNP from the [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS tools]] and [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS tools]]. Excluding the non-oil & gas nations (e.g. Qatar, Norway), and micro jurisdictions, the resulting highest [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita#Distorted GDP-per-capita for tax havens|GDP-per-capita]] countries are tax havens, led by: Luxembourg (#1), Singapore (#2), and Ireland (#3). }}
===Top 10 tax havens===
The post–2010 rise in quantitative techniques of identifying tax havens has seen a consistency amongst the ten largest tax havens. [[Dhammika Dharmapala|Dharmapala]] notes that as corporate BEPS flows dominate tax haven activity, these are mostly corporate tax havens.<ref name="be"/> Nine of the top ten tax havens in [[Gabriel Zucman]]'s June 2018 study appear in the top ten lists of the two other quantitative studies since 2010. Four of the top five Conduit OFCs are represented; however, the United Kingdom only [[Corporate haven#U.K. transformation|transformed its tax code]] in 2009–2012. All five of the top 5 Sink OFCs are represented, although Jersey only appears in the Hines 2010 list.
The studies capture the rise of Ireland and Singapore, both major regional headquarters for some of the largest BEPS tool users, Apple, Google and Facebook.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/tech-giants-eating-up-dublin-s-office-market-1.3455742|title=Tech giants eating up Dublin’s office market|publisher=Irish Times|date=18 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/10/googles-new-apac-headquarters-in-singapore-is-a-blend-of-office-building-and-tech-campus.html|title=Google's new APAC headquarters in Singapore is a blend of office building and tech campus|publisher=CNBC|date=November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/facebook-s-singapore-office-will-make-you-want-to-quit-your-job-a6675511.html|title=Facebook’s Singapore APAC Headquarters|publisher=The Independent|date=October 2015}}</ref>
In Q1 2015, Apple completed the largest BEPS action in history, when it shifted USD 300 billion of IP to Ireland, which Nobel-prize economist [[Paul Krugman]] called "[[leprechaun economics]]".
In September 2018, using TCJA repatriation tax data, the [[National Bureau of Economic Research|NBER]] listed the ''key tax havens'' as: "Ireland, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Switzerland, Singapore, Bermuda and [the] Caribbean havens".<ref name="zucwright"/><ref name="japantimes"/>
{| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: left;" | Comparison of top ten tax havens from the major quantitative studies since 2010: |- ! style="text-align:left" | List ! style="text-align:left" | [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines 2010 list|Hines 2010]]<ref name="h1"/> ! style=";text-align:left" | [[Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy#ITEP 2017 tax haven list (by quantum of profits)|ITEP 2017]]{{efn|name=ITEP}}<ref name="ITEP"/> ! style=";text-align:left" | [[Gabriel Zucman#Zucman-Tørsløv-Wier 2018 list|Zucman 2018]]<ref name="gbz"/> |- ! style="text-align:left" | Quantum ! style="text-align:left" | [[Foreign direct investment|FDI]] ! style=";text-align:left" |Profits ! style=";text-align:left" |[[BEPS]] |- ! style="text-align:left" | Rank |- | 1 || align="left" | Luxembourg*‡ || Netherlands*† || Ireland*† |- | 2 || align="left" | Cayman Islands* || Ireland*† || Caribbean: Cayman Islands*<br>& British Virgin Islands*‡Δ |- | 3 || align="left" | Ireland*† || Bermuda*‡ || Singapore*† |- | 4 || align="left" | Switzerland*† || Luxembourg*‡ || Switzerland*† |- | 5 || align="left" | Bermuda*‡ || Cayman Islands* || Netherlands*† |- | 6 || align="left" | Hong Kong*‡ || Switzerland*† || Luxembourg*‡ |- | 7 || align="left" | Jersey‡Δ || Singapore*† || Puerto Rico |- | 8 || align="left" | Netherlands*† || BahamasΔ || Hong Kong*‡ |- | 9 || align="left" | Singapore*† || Hong Kong*‡ || Bermuda*‡ |- | 10 || align="left" | British Virgin Islands*‡Δ || British Virgin Islands*‡Δ || (n.a. as "Caribbean"<br>contains 2 havens) |}
(*) Appears as a top ten tax haven in all three lists; 9 major tax havens meet this criterion, ''Ireland, Singapore, Switzerland and the Netherlands (the Conduit OFCs), and the Cayman Islands, British Virgin Islands, Luxembourg, Hong Kong and Bermuda (the Sink OFCs)''.<br> (†) Also appears as one of 5 [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFC]] (Ireland, Singapore, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom), in CORPNET's 2017 research; or<br> (‡) Also appears as a Top 5 [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFC]] (British Virgin Islands, Luxemburg, Hong Kong, Jersey, Bermuda), in CORPNET's 2017 research.<br> (Δ) Identified on the first, and largest, OECD 2000 list of 35 tax havens (the OECD list only contained Trinidad & Tobago by 2017).<ref name="OECDh"/>
The strongest consensus amongst academics regarding the world's largest tax havens is therefore: Ireland, Singapore, Switzerland and the Netherlands (the major Conduit OFCs), and the Cayman Islands, British Virgin Islands, Luxembourg, Hong Kong and Bermuda (the major Sink OFCs), with the United Kingdom (a major Conduit OFC) still in transformation.
Of these ten major havens, all except the United Kingdom and the Netherlands featured on the original [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines-Rice 1994 list|Hines–Rice 1994 list]]. The United Kingdom was not a tax haven in 1994, and Hines estimated the Netherlands's effective tax rate in 1994 at over 20% (he estimated Ireland’s at 4%). Four of them, Ireland, Singapore, Switzerland (3 of the 5 top Conduit OFCs), and Hong Kong (a top 5 Sink OFC), featured in the Hines–Rice 1994 list's ''7 major tax havens'' sub–category; highlighting a lack of progress in curtailing tax havens.<ref name="h3"/>
In terms of [[Corporate haven#Proxy tests|proxy indicators]], this list, excluding Canada, contains all seven of the countries that received more than one US [[tax inversion]] since 1982 (see [[Corporate haven#Bloomberg Corporate tax inversions|here]])<ref name="bbb"/>. In addition, six of these major tax havens are in the top 15 [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita#Distorted GDP-per-capita for tax havens|GDP-per-capita]], and of the four others, three of them, the Caribbean locations, are not included in IMF-World Bank GDP-per-capita tables.
In a June 2018 joint IMF report into the effect of BEPS flows on global economic data, eight of the above (excluding Switzerland and the United Kingdon) were cited as the world’s leading tax havens.<ref name="imfx"/>

===Broad lists of tax havens===
Post–2010 research on tax havens is focused on quantitative analysis (which can be ranked), and tends to ignore very small tax havens where data is limited as the haven is used for individual tax avoidance rather than corporate tax avoidance. The last credible broad unranked list of global tax havens is the [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines 2010 list|James Hines 2010 list]] of 52 tax havens. It is shown below but expanded to 55 to include havens identified in the July 2017 [[Conduit and Sink OFCs]] study that were not considered havens in 2010, namely the United Kingdom, Taiwan, and Curaçao. The James Hines 2010 list contains 34 of the original 35 OCED tax havens;<ref name="OECDh"/> and compared with the {{slink|#Top 10 tax havens}} and {{slink|#Top 20 tax havens}} above, show OECD processes focus on the compliance of tiny havens.

Major sovereign States which feature on financial secrecy lists (e.g. the [[Financial Secrecy Index]]), but not on [[corporate tax haven]] or traditional tax haven lists, are:
* United States – noted for secrecy, per the [[Financial Secrecy Index]], (see [[United States as a tax haven]]); makes a "controversial" appearance on some lists.<ref name="Drucker2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-27/the-world-s-favorite-new-tax-haven-is-the-united-states|title=The World’s Favorite New Tax Haven Is the United States|author=Jesse Drucker|date=27 January 2016|work=Bloomberg.com}}</ref> * [[Germany]] – similar to the U.S., Germany can be included on lists for its tax secrecy, per the Financial Secrecy Index<ref>{{cite web|url=https://global.handelsblatt.com/finance/a-german-tax-haven-626845|title=A German Tax Haven|website=Handelsblatt Global|date=25 October 2016|first = Konrad|last = Fischer}}</ref>
Neither the U.S. or Germany have appeared on any tax haven lists by the main academic leaders in tax haven research, namely: [[James R. Hines Jr.]], [[Dhammika Dharmapala]] or [[Gabriel Zucman]]. There are no known cases of foreign firms executing [[tax inversion]]s to the U.S. or Germany for tax purposes, a basic sense-check of a [[corporate tax haven]].<ref name="bbb"/>
===Former tax havens===
* [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]] formerly had a reputation as the only tax haven in the [[Middle East]]. However, this changed after the [[Intra Bank]] crash of 1966,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,945606-1,00.html |title= Lebanon: Election Under Fire|work =Time Magazine|date=17 May 1976|accessdate = |url-access=subscription}}</ref> and the subsequent political and military deterioration of Lebanon dissuaded foreign use of the country as a tax haven. * [[Liberia]] had a prosperous [[flag of convenience|ship registration industry]]. The series of violent and bloody [[First Liberian Civil War|civil wars]] in the 1990s and early 2000s severely damaged confidence in the country. The fact that the ship registration business still continues is partly a testament to its early success, and partly a testament to moving the national shipping registry to New York, United States. * [[Tangier]] had a short existence as a tax haven in the period between the end of effective control by the Spanish in 1945 until it was formally reunited with [[Morocco]] in 1956. * Some Pacific islands were tax havens but were curtailed by OECD demands for regulation and transparency in the late 1990s, on the threat of blacklisting. [[Vanuatu]]'s Financial Services commissioner said in May 2008 that his country would reform laws and cease being a tax haven. "We've been associated with this stigma for a long time and we now aim to get away from being a tax haven."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23652068-2702,00.html |title = Vanuatu to ditch tax haven|first= Anthony |last=Klan|work =The Australian|date= 6 May 2008|deadurl = no|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080507013228/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23652068-2702,00.html|archivedate = 7 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-11-15/the-final-days-of-a-tax-haven|title= The Final Days of a Tax Haven|publisher=Bloomberg|date=15 November 2017|last = Bremner|first = Brian}}</ref>

The [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] estimated in 2007 that capital held offshore amounted to between $5 trillion and $7 trillion, making up approximately 6–8% of total global investments under management.<ref name="Places in the sun">[http://www.economist.com/surveys/displaystory.cfm?story_id=8695139 "Places in the sun"], ''The Economist'', 22 February 2007. This may be a slight underestimate: according to the Cayman Islands Monetary Authority, Caymanian licensed banks held US$1.725 trillion in deposits as of September 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.cimoney.com.ky/stats_reg_ent/stats_reg_ent.aspx?id=200&ekmensel=e2f22c9a_14_72_200_6|title=Banking statistics|accessdate=2013-02-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130303181908/http://www.cimoney.com.ky/stats_reg_ent/stats_reg_ent.aspx?id=200&ekmensel=e2f22c9a_14_72_200_6|archive-date=3 March 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A more recent study by [[Gabriel Zucman]] of the [[London School of Economics]] estimated the amount of global cross-border wealth held in tax havens (including the Netherlands and Luxembourg as tax havens for this purpose) at US$7.6 trillion, of which US$2.46 trillion was held in Switzerland alone.<ref name=Zucman /><ref name="zucc">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/08/tax-havens-dodging-theft-multinationals-avoiding-tax|title=The desperate inequality behind global tax dodging|publisher=The Guardian| date=8 November 2017}}</ref> The [[Tax Justice Network]] (an anti-tax haven pressure group) estimated in 2012 that capital held offshore amounted to between $21 trillion and $32 trillion (between 24–32% of total global investments),<ref name="TOI">{{cite web |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-07-22/news/32788549_1_tax-havens-tax-justice-network-investment-bank| title=13 trillion pounds in offshore tax havens: Report | publisher=The Times of India | date=22 July 2012 | accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="Reuters">{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/07/22/uk-offshore-wealth-idUKBRE86L03W20120722?feedType=RSS&feedname=topNews | title=Super rich hold $32 trillion in offshore havens | publisher=Reuters | date=22 July 2012 | accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18944097 |title=Tax havens: Super-rich 'hiding' at least $21tn | publisher=BBC | date=22 July 2012 | accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref> although those estimates have been challenged.<ref name="Gordon & Morriss" />
In 2000, the [[International Monetary Fund]] calculated based on [[Bank for International Settlements]] data that for selected [[offshore financial centre]]s, [[balance sheet|on-balance sheet]] cross-border assets held in offshore financial centres reached a level of $4.6 trillion at the end of June 1999 (about 50 percent of total cross-border assets). Of that $4.6 trillion, $0.9 trillion was held in the Caribbean, $1 trillion in Asia, and most of the remaining $2.7 trillion accounted for by the major [[international financial centre|international finance centre]]s (IFCs), namely London, the U.S. IBFs, and the Japanese offshore market.<ref>[http://www.imf.org/external/np/mae/oshore/2000/eng/back.htm "Offshore Financial Centers"], International Monetary Fund background paper, 23 June 2000</ref> The [[U.S. Department of Treasury]] estimated that in 2011 the Caribbean Banking Centers, which include Bahamas, Bermuda, Cayman Islands, Netherlands Antilles and Panama, held almost $2 trillion in United States debt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/tic/Pages/ticliab.aspx |title=U.S. Banking Liabilities to Foreigners. |publisher=Treasury.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-03-22}}</ref> Of this, approximately US$1.4 trillion is estimated to be held in the Cayman Islands alone.<ref name="Places in the sun"/>
The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' in a study of 60 large U.S. companies found that they deposited $166 billion in offshore accounts in 2012, sheltering over 40% of their profits from U.S. taxes.<ref name="ThurmLinebaugh" /> Similarly, Desai, Foley and Hines found that: "in 1999, 59% of U.S. firms with significant foreign operations had affiliates in tax haven countries", although they did not define "significant" for this purpose.<ref name="desai">{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0047272705001350 |author1=[[Mihir A. Desai]]|author2=C Fritz Foley|author3=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|title=The demand for tax haven operations | journal=[[Journal of Public Economics]] | volume=90 | issue=3 | pages=513-531 | date=February 2006|quote=Examples of such tax havens include Ireland and Luxembourg in Europe, Hong Kong and Singapore in Asia, and various Caribbean island nations in the Americas}}</ref> In 2009, the [[Government Accountability Office|U.S. Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) reported that 83 of the 100 largest U.S. publicly traded corporations and 63 of the 100 largest contractors for the U.S. federal government were maintaining subsidiaries in countries generally considered havens for avoiding taxes. The GAO did not review the companies' transactions to independently verify that the subsidiaries helped the companies reduce their tax burden, but said only that historically the purpose of such subsidiaries is to cut tax costs.<ref>{{cite news |title=Report Finds Major U.S. Companies Have Offshore Tax Havens |author=Carol D. Leonnig |work=Washington Post |date=16 January 2009 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/16/AR2009011602602.html?hpid=topnews }}</ref>
James Henry, former chief economist at consultants [[McKinsey & Company]], in his report for the Tax Justice Network gives an indication of the amount of money that is sheltered by wealthy individuals in tax havens. The report estimated conservatively that a fortune of $21 trillion is stashed away in off-shore accounts with $9.8 trillion alone by the top tier—less than 100,000 people—who each own financial assets of $30 million or more. The report's author indicated that this hidden money results in a "huge" lost tax revenue—a "black hole" in the economy—and many countries would become creditors instead of being debtors if the money of their tax evaders would be taxed.<ref name="TOI" /><ref name="Reuters" /><ref name="BBC" />
===Lost tax revenue=== [[File:HMRC offshore evasion poster February 2014.jpg|thumbnail|Poster issued by the British tax authorities to counter illegal offshore tax evasion.]] The Tax Justice Network estimated in 2012 that global tax revenue lost to tax havens was circa $190 to $255 billion per year (assuming a 3% [[capital gains]] rate, a 30% [[capital gains tax]] rate, and $21 to $32 trillion hidden in tax havens.<ref name=tjn12 /> The [[Gabriel Zucman|Zucman]] study uses different methodology, but also estimates $190 billion in lost revenue.<ref name=Zucman/>
The UN Economic Commission for Africa estimates that illegal financial flows cost the continent around $50 billion per year. The [[OECD]] estimates that two-thirds ($30 billion) occur from tax avoidance and evasion from non-African firms.<ref name="D+C">{{cite news |title=Misleading index|url=https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/corruption-africa-preconceptions-and-hidden-perpetrators|author= Nico Beckert|work=D+C, development and cooperation |date=21 February 2017 |accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> The avoidance of taxation by international corporations through legal and illegal methods stifles development in African countries. The [[Sustainable Development Goals]] (SDGs) will be difficult to obtain if these losses persist.<ref name="E+Z">{{cite news |title=Missing Billions|url=https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/international-oil-gas-and-mining-corporations-are-cheating-developing-countries-out-tax|author=Nico Beckert|work=D+C, development and cooperation |date=28 December 2017 |accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref>
In 2016 a massive data leak known as the "[[Panama Papers]]" cast some doubt on the size of previous estimates of lost revenue.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2016/04/10/david-camerons-panama-papers-show-how-little-offshore-tax-dodging-is-going-on/#4d465ae92a0d |title=David Cameron's Panama Papers Show How Little Offshore Tax Dodging Is Going On |publisher=Forbes |date=10 April 2016 | quote=We’ve got evidence of offshore structures, most assuredly we have. But not only haven’t we got any evidence of tax dodging all the evidence we do have points to less tax dodging than many think.}}</ref>
However, the tax policy director of the [[Chartered Institute of Taxation]] expressed skepticism over the accuracy of the figures.<ref name="bbc.co.uk" /> If true, those sums would amount to approximately 5 to 8 times the [[Circulation (currency)|total amount of currency presently in circulation]] in the world. [[Daniel J. Mitchell]] of the [[Cato Institute]] says that the report also assumes, when considering notional lost tax revenue, that 100% money deposited offshore is evading payment of tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesovereigninvestor.com/2012/07/30/fighting-anti-tax-haven-demagoguery-on-cnn/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227214302/http://thesovereigninvestor.com/2012/07/30/fighting-anti-tax-haven-demagoguery-on-cnn/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-12-27|title=Fighting Anti-Tax Haven Demagoguery on CNN|date=2012-07-30|accessdate=2012-10-03}}</ref>
In October 2009, research commissioned from [[Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu|Deloitte]] for the Foot Review of British Offshore Financial Centres said that much less tax had been lost to tax havens than previously had been thought. The report indicated "We estimate the total UK corporation tax potentially lost to avoidance activities to be up to £2 billion per annum, although it could be much lower." An earlier report by the U.K. [[Trades Union Congress]], concluded that tax avoidance by the 50 largest companies in the [[FTSE 100 Index|FTSE 100]] was depriving the [[UK Treasury]] of approximately £11.8 billion.<ref name="The Times">{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article6896141.ece|title=Tax haven report lays emphasis on vital role of Crown Dependencies|author=''[[The Times]]''|date=2009-10-30|accessdate=2009-11-02 | location=London}}</ref> The report also stressed that [[British Crown Dependencies]] make a "significant contribution to the liquidity of the UK market". In the second quarter of 2009, they provided net funds to banks in the UK totaling $323 billion (£195 billion), of which $218 billion came from [[Jersey]], $74 billion from [[Guernsey]] and $40 billion from the [[Isle of Man]].<ref name="The Times"/>
The Tax Justice Network reports that this system is "basically designed and operated" by a group of highly paid specialists from the world’s largest private banks (led by [[UBS]], [[Credit Suisse]], and [[Goldman Sachs]]), law offices, and accounting firms and tolerated by international organizations such as Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the OECD, and the [[G20]]. The amount of money hidden away has significantly increased since 2005, sharpening the divide between the super-rich and the rest of the world.<ref name="TOI" /><ref name="Reuters" /><ref name="BBC" />
The [[World Bank]], in its 2019 [[World Development Report]] on the future of work [http://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/wdr2019 supports] increased government efforts to curb tax avoidance in order to create fiscal space for human capital investments.
==Incentives for tax havens== {{see also|Corporate haven#GDP-per-capita tax haven proxy|List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita#Distorted GDP-per-capita for tax havens}}
===Inflated GDP-per-capita===
[[File:Paul Krugman at the German National Library in Frankfurt.jpg|thumb|Nobel Prize-winning economist [[Paul Krugman]] called the 2015 restatement of Ireland's national accounts, as a result of the Q1 2015 restructuring of Apple's BEPS tools in Ireland, "[[leprechaun economics]]", due to the extreme levels of distortion that BEPS tools were having on Irish GDP/GNP. In February 2017, Ireland replaced GDP/GNP with "[[Modified gross national income|Modified GNI]]".]]
Tax havens, traditional and corporate, have high [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita|GDP-per-capita]] rankings, because the haven's national economic statistics are artificially inflated by the [[BEPS]] accounting flows that add to the haven's GDP (and even GNP), but are not taxable in the haven.<ref name="imfx">{{cite journal|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2018/06/inside-the-world-of-global-tax-havens-and-offshore-banking/damgaard.htm|title=Piercing the Veil of Tax Havens |first1 = Jannick |last1=Damgaard|first2=Thomas|last2= Elkjaer|first3=Niels |last3=Johannesen | journal=International Monetary Fund: [[Finance & Development|Finance & Development Quarterly]]|quote=The eight major pass-through economies—the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Hong Kong SAR, the British Virgin Islands, Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, Ireland, and Singapore—host more than 85 percent of the world’s investment in special purpose entities, which are often set up for tax reasons.|volume=55|issue =2|date= June 2018}}</ref><ref name="qqtz">{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/1300880/tax-havens-mean-40-of-foreign-direct-investments-are-artificial/|title=How tax havens turn economic statistics into nonsense|publisher=Quartz|date=11 June 2018}}</ref> As the largest facilitators of BEPS flows, corporate-focused tax havens, in particular, make up most of the top 10-15 GDP-per-capita tables, excluding oil and gas nations (see table below). Research into tax havens suggest a high GDP-per-capita score, in the absence of material natural resources, as an important [[Corporate haven#Proxy tests|proxy indicator]] of a tax haven.<ref name="imf">IMF working paper: [http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2007/wp0787.pdf Concept of Offshore Financial Centers: In Search of an Operational Definition; Ahmed Zoromé; IMF Working Paper 07/87; April 1, 2007]. (PDF) . Retrieved on 2011-11-02.</ref> At the core of the FSF-IMF definition of an [[offshore financial centre]] is a country where the BEPS flows are out of proportion to the size of the indigenous economy. Apple's Q1 2015 "[[leprechaun economics]]" BEPS transaction in Ireland was a dramatic example, which caused Ireland to abandon its GDP and GNP metrics in February 2017, in favour of a new metric, [[modified gross national income]], or GNI*.
This artificial inflation of GDP can attract excess foreign capital, who misprice their capital by using a Debt-to-GDP metric for the haven, thus producing phases of stronger economic growth.<ref name="mich">{{cite journal|url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/39181/921.pdf?sequence=1|title=Do Tax Havens Flourish|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|journal=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], ''Tax Policy and the Economy''|quote=ABSTRACT: Per capita real GDP in tax haven countries grew at an average annual rate of 3.3 percent between 1982 and 1999, which compares favorably to the world average of 1.4 percent.|volume=19|page=65-99|date=2005}}</ref> However, the increased leverage leads to more severe credit cycles, particularly where the artificial nature of the GDP is exposed to foreign investors.<ref name="atlantic">{{cite web| url = https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/07/tax-haven-curse/491411/|title=Why Tax Havens are Political and Economic disasters|publisher=The Atlantic|date=28 July 2016}}</ref> An example is the Irish financial crisis in 2009–2013.<ref name="ber">{{cite web|url=https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/p_imk_wp_175_2017.pdf|author=Heike Joebges|title=CRISIS RECOVERY IN A COUNTRY WITH A HIGH PRESENCE OF FOREIGN-OWNED COMPANIES: The Case of Ireland |publisher=IMK Macroeconomic Policy Institute, [[Hans-Böckler-Stiftung]]|date=January 2017}}</ref>
