===Importance of governance===
In several research papers, [[James R. Hines Jr.]] showed that tax havens were typically small but well-governed nations and that being a tax haven had brought significant prosperity.<ref name="h2"/><ref name="mich"/> In 2009, Hines and Dharmapala suggested that roughly 15% of countries are tax havens, but they wondered why more countries had not become tax havens given the observable economic prosperity it could bring.<ref name="dhar"/>
{{quote|There are roughly 40 major tax havens in the world today, but the sizable apparent economic returns to becoming a tax haven raise the question of why there are not more.|source=Which Countries Become Tax Havens? (2009)<ref name="dhar"/>|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]], [[James R. Hines Jr.]]}}
Hines and Dharmapala concluded that governance was a major issue for smaller countries in trying to become tax havens. Only countries with strong governance and legislation which was trusted by foreign corporates and investors, would become tax havens.<ref name="dhar"/> Hines and Dharmapala's positive view on the financial benefits of becoming a tax haven, as well as being two of the major academic leaders into tax haven research, put them in sharp conflict with non-governmental organisations advocating ''tax justice'', such as the Tax Justice Network, who accused them as promoting tax avoidance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://taxjustice.blogspot.com/2010/03/jim-hines-fails-to-defend-secrecy.html|title=Jim Hines fails to defend secrecy jurisdictions|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=3 March 2010}}</ref><ref name="ns1">{{cite web|url=http://treasureislands.org/the-arguments/|title=Tax havens’ arguments in their defence – and why they are wrong |quote=First, many these claims rest heavily on work done by James Hines of the University of Michigan and a few others – research that is fatally flawed. |author=[[Nicholas Shaxson]]|date=19 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="ns2">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/five-myths-about-tax-havens/2016/04/15/76d001d2-0255-11e6-b823-707c79ce3504_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.9d79e83386b9|title=Five myths about tax havens|quote=According to economics professor James Hines, tax havens serve as healthy competition for high-tax countries, nudging them toward less-restrictive financial policy. By providing alternatives to tightly controlled financial sectors, Hines wrote in a 2010 paper, tax havens discourage regulations that act as “a drag on local economies.”|publisher=The Washington Post|author=[[Nicholas Shaxson]]|date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
==Benefits of tax havens==
===U.S. as the largest beneficiary===
An unexpected conclusion of the original 1994 [[James R. Hines Jr.#Tax haven research|Hines-Rice paper]], and re-affirmed by others,<ref name="praise">{{cite journal|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/9fa3/80280acbdf02a218407dc38cf909d0260b6e.pdf|title=In praise of tax havens: International tax planning and foreign direct investment|journal=[[European Economic Review]]|volume=54|issue=1|pages=82-95|date=January 2010|author1=Qing Hong|author2=Michael Smart}}</ref> was that: ''low foreign tax rates [from tax havens] ultimately enhance U.S. tax collections''.<ref name="h3"/> Hines noted that as a result of paying no foreign taxes by using tax havens, U.S. multinationals had avoided building up foreign tax credits that would reduce their ultimate U.S. tax liability. Hines returned to this finding several times, and in his 2010 {{slink|#Important papers on tax havens}}, ''Treasure Islands'', where he showed how U.S. multinationals used tax havens and BEPS tools to avoid Japanese taxes on their Japanese investments, noted that this was being confirmed by other empirical research at a company-level.<ref name="dryng">{{cite journal|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1475-679X.2009.00346.x|title=Using Financial Accounting Data to Examine the Effect of Foreign Operations Located in Tax Havens and Other Countries on US Multinational Firms' Tax Rates|author1=Scott Dyreng|author2=Bradley P. Lindsey|date=12 October 2009|quote=Finally, we find that US firms with operations in some tax haven countries have higher federal tax rates on foreign income than other firms. This result suggests that in some cases, tax haven operations may increase US tax collections at the expense of foreign country tax collections.|journal=[[Journal of Accounting Research]]}}</ref> Hines's observations would influence U.S. policy towards tax havens, including the 1996 "[[Entity classification election|check-the-box]]"{{efn|name="check"|Before 1996, the United States, like other high-income countries, had anti-avoidance rules—known as “controlled foreign corporations” provisions—designed to immediately tax in the United States some foreign income (such as royalties and interest) conducive of profit shifting. In 1996, the IRS issued regulations that enabled U.S. multinationals to avoid some of these rules by electing to treat their foreign subsidiaries as if they were not corporations but disregarded entities for tax purposes. This move is called “checking the box” because that is all that needs to be done on IRS form 8832 to make it work and use Irish BEPS tools on non-U.S. revenues was a compromise to keep U.S. multinationals from leaving the U.S. (page 10.)<ref name="zucwright"/>}} rules, and U.S. hostility to OECD attempts in curbing Ireland's BEPS tools,{{efn|The U.S. refused to sign the [[BEPS#OECD BEPS Project|OECD BEPS Multilateral Instrument]] ("MLI") on the 24 November 2016.}}<ref name="crs2"/> and why, in spite of public disclosure of tax avoidance by firms such as Google, Facebook, and Apple, with Irish BEPS tools, [[Ireland as a tax haven#Apparent contradictions|little has been done by the U.S. to stop them]].<ref name="praise"/>
[[File:Where do U.S. multinationals book their profits (2016 BEA).png|thumb|upright=1.6|U.S. multinationals book over half of their non-U.S. profits in tax havens by using BEPS tools (2016 [[Bureau of Economic Analysis|BEA]]).<ref name="zucwright"/><ref name="japantimes"/>]]
{{quote|Lower foreign tax rates entail smaller credits for foreign taxes and greater ultimate U.S. tax collections (Hines and Rice, 1994).<ref name="h3"/> Dyreng and Lindsey (2009),<ref name="dryng"/> offer evidence that U.S. firms with foreign affiliates in certain tax havens pay lower pay lower foreign taxes and higher U.S. taxes than do otherwise-similar large U.S. companies.|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]] |source="Treasure Islands" p. 107 (2010)<ref name="h1"/>}}
Research in June-September 2018, confirmed U.S. multinationals as the largest global users of tax havens and [[BEPS]] tools.<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|author= Richard Rubin|quote=U.S. companies are the most aggressive users of profit-shifting techniques, which often relocate paper profits without bringing jobs and wages, according to the study by economists Thomas Torslov and Ludvig Wier of the University of Copenhagen and Gabriel Zucman of the University of California, Berkeley|date=10 June 2018|title=Corporations Push Profits Into Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Study Says}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nordic.businessinsider.com/new-research-finds-40-of-multinationals-profits-shifted-to-tax-havens--eu-biggest-loser-while-us-firms-most-shifty--/|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|title=New research finds 40% of multinationals’ profits shifted to tax havens – EU biggest loser while US firms most shifty|date=20 July 2018}}</ref>
{{quote|U.S. multinationals use tax havens{{efn|The paper lists tax havens as: ''Ireland, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Switzerland, Singapore, Bermuda and Caribbean havens'' (page 6.)}} more than multinationals from other countries which have kept their controlled foreign corporations regulations. No other non-haven OECD country records as high a share of foreign profits booked in tax havens as the United States. [...] This suggests that half of all the global profits shifted to tax havens are shifted by U.S. multinationals. By contrast, about 25% accrues to E.U. countries, 10% to the rest of the OECD, and 15% to developing countries (Tørsløv et al., 2018).|source=[[Gabriel Zucman]], Thomas Wright, "The Exorbitant Tax Privilege", [[National Bureau of Economic Research|NBER]] Working Papers (September 2018).<ref name="zucwright">{{cite journal |url= http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/WrightZucman2018.pdf|title=The Exorbitant Tax Privilege|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]]|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|page=11|author2=Thomas Wright|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref name="japantimes">{{cite web |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/09/11/business/half-u-s-foreign-profits-booked-tax-havens-especially-ireland-paper/#.W5eRKkZKhPY|title=Half of U.S. foreign profits booked in tax havens, especially Ireland: NBER paper|publisher=''[[The Japan Times]]''|quote=“Ireland solidifies its position as the #1 tax haven,” Zucman said on Twitter. “U.S. firms book more profits in Ireland than in China, Japan, Germany, France & Mexico combined. Irish tax rate: 5.7%.”|date=10 September 2018}}</ref>}}
''Tax justice'' groups interpreted Hines' research as the U.S. engaging in tax competition with higher-tax nations (i.e. the U.S. exchequer earning excess taxes at the expense of others). The 2017 TCJA seems to support this view with the U.S. exchequer being able to levy a 15.5% repatriation tax on over $1 trillion of untaxed offshore profits built up by U.S. multinationals with BEPS tools from non-U.S. revenues. Had these U.S. multinationals paid taxes on these non-U.S. profits in the countries in which they were earned, there would have been the little further liability to U.S. taxation. Research by Zucman and Wright (2018) estimated that most of the TCJA repatriation benefit went to the shareholders of U.S. multinationals, and not the U.S. exchequer.<ref name="zucwright"/>{{efn|Zucman and Wright's analysis assumed that U.S. multinationals were going to pay a U.S. 35% rate eventually (e.g. they would repatriate their untaxed offshore cash at some stage in the future); if the assumption is made that they were going to permanently leave their offshore cash outside of the U.S., then the U.S. exchequer was the main beneficiary}}
Academics who study tax havens, attribute Washington's support of U.S. multinational use of tax havens to a "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Source of contradictions|political compromise]]" between Washington, and even other higher-tax OECD nations, to compensate for the shortcomings of the U.S. "worldwide" tax system.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL34115.pdf|title=Reform of U.S. International Taxation: Alternatives|publisher=[[Congressional Research Service]]|author=Jane G. Gravelle|date=1 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Tax havens: How Globalization Really Works|url=https://academic.oup.com/joeg/article-abstract/11/4/753/918739?redirectedFrom=fulltext#|publisher=[[Cornell University Press]]|author1=[[Ronen Palan]]|author2=[[Richard Murphy (tax campaigner)|Richard Murphy]]|author3=Christian Chavagneux|date=1 July 2011|isbn=978-0801476129}}</ref> Hines had advocated for a switch to a "territorial" tax system, as most other nations use, which would remove U.S. multinational need for tax havens. In 2016, Hines, with German tax academics, showed that German multinationals make little use of tax havens because their tax regime, a "territorial" system, removes any need for it.<ref>{{cite journal| url = https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2831&context=articles|title=Multinational Firms and Tax Havens|author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Anna Gumpert|author3=Monika Schnitzer|date=2016|journal=[[The Review of Economics and Statistics]]|page=714|quote=Germany taxes only 5% of the active foreign business profits of its resident corporations. [..] Furthermore, German firms do not have incentives to structure their foreign operations in ways that avoid repatriating income. Therefore, the tax incentives for German firms to establish tax haven affiliates are likely to differ from those of U.S. firms and bear strong similarities to those of other G-7 and OECD firms.|volume=98|issue=4}}</ref>
Hines' research was cited by the by the [[Council of Economic Advisors]] ("CEA") in drafting the TCJA legislation in 2017, and advocating for moving to a hybrid "territorial" tax system framework.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/documents/Tax%20Reform%20and%20Wages.pdf|publisher=[[Council of Economic Advisors]]|title=Corporate Tax Reform and Wages: Theory and Evidence|quote=Applying Hines and Rice’s (1994) findings to a statutory corporate rate reduction of 15 percentage points (from 35 to 20 percent) suggests that reduced profit shifting would result in more than $140 billion of repatriated profit based on 2016 numbers.|date=17 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/17/us/politics/white-house-push-to-help-workers-through-corporate-tax-cut-draws-skepticism.html|title=White House Push to Help Workers Through Corporate Tax Cut Draws Skepticism|publisher=New York Times|date=17 October 2017|quote=But the CEA did not misinterpret the Desai, Foley, and Hines paper.}}</ref>
===Promoters of global growth=== [[File:Joel Slemrod C-SPAN.jpg|thumb|[[Joel Slemrod]] testifying to the [[President's Advisory Panel for Federal Tax Reform]] (2005). Slemrod rejected Hines, Desai, and Dharmapala's observations, that tax havens might support global economic growth, instead calling tax havens ''parasitic''.<ref name="slemrod"/>]]
A controversial area of research into tax havens is the suggestion that tax havens actually promote global economic growth by solving perceived issues in the tax regimes of higher-taxed nations (e.g. the above discussion on the U.S. "worldwide" tax system as an example). Important academic leaders in tax haven research, such as Hines,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/04/tax-havens-and-treasure-hunts/|title=Tax havens and treasure hunts|publisher=[[New York Times]]|quote=Some economists champion tax havens. In an article in the Journal of Economic Perspectives published last fall (also titled “Treasure Islands”), James R. Hines Jr. of the University of Michigan argued that they contribute to financial market competition, encourage investment in high-tax countries and promote economic growth. Like many economists, Professor Hines expresses far more confidence in the market than in the state. He worries more about possible overtaxation than about undertaxation of corporate income. He does not enage with such concepts as “tax justice.”|date=11 April 2011}}</ref> Dharmapala,<ref name="dhh"/> and others,<ref name="praise"/> cite evidence that, in certain cases, tax havens appear to promote economic growth in higher-tax countries, and can support beneficial hybrid tax regimes of higher taxes on domestic activity, but lower taxes on international sourced capital or income:
{{quote| The effect of tax havens on economic welfare in high tax countries is unclear, though the availability of tax havens appears to stimulate economic activity in nearby high-tax countries.|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]] |source="Abstract: Tax Havens" (2007)<ref name="h2"/>}}
{{quote|Tax havens change the nature of tax competition among other countries, very possibly permitting them to sustain high domestic tax rates that are effectively mitigated for mobile international investors whose transactions are routed through tax havens. [..] In fact, countries that lie close to tax havens have exhibited more rapid real income growth than have those further away, possibly in part as a result of financial flows and their market effects.|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]] |source="Treasure Islands" p. 107 (2010)<ref name="h1"/>}}
The most cited paper on research into [[offshore financial centres]] ("OFCs"),<ref name="respecOFC">{{cite web|url=https://ideas.repec.org/cgi-bin/htsearch?form=extended&wm=wrd&dt=range&ul=&q=tax+haven&cmd=Search%21&wf=4BFF&s=C&db=&de=|title=IDEAS/RePEc Database|quote=Offshore Financial Centres by Most Cited}}</ref> a closely related term to tax havens, noted the positive and negative aspects of OFCs on neighbouring high-tax, or source, economies, and marginally came out in favour of OFCs.<ref name="RoseSpiegel">{{cite journal|url=http://www.nber.org/papers/w12044.pdf|title=Offshore Financial Centers: Parasites or Symbionts?|author1=Andrew K. Rose|author2=Mark M. Spiegel|date=21 September 2007|publisher=[[The Economic Journal]]|volume=117|issue=523|pages=1310-1335}}</ref>
{{quote|CONCLUSION: Using both bilateral and multilateral samples, we find empirically that successful offshore financial centers encourage bad behavior in source countries since they facilitate tax evasion and money laundering [...] Nevertheless, offshore financial centers created to facilitate undesirable activities can still have unintended positive consequences. [...] We tentatively conclude that OFCs are better characterized as "symbionts".|source=Andrew K. Rose, Mark M. Spiegel, "Offshore Financial Centers: Parasites or Symbionts?", [[The Economic Journal]], (September 2007)<ref name="RoseSpiegel"/>}}
However, other notable tax academics strongly dispute these views, such as work by [[Joel Slemrod|Slemrod]] and Wilson, who in their {{slink|#Important papers on tax havens}}, label tax havens as ''parasitic'' to jurisdictions with normal tax regimes, that can damage their economies.<ref name="slemrod">{{cite journal|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/teaching/SlemrodWilson09.pdf|title=Tax competition with parasitic tax havens|date=6 September 2009|journal=[[Journal of Public Economics]]|author1=[[Joel Slemrod]]|author2=John D. Wilson|quote=Although a previous literature has modelled tax havens as a benign phenomenon that helps high-tax countries reduce the negative impact of their own suboptimal domestic tax policies, there is considerable concern that the havens are “parasitic” on the tax revenues of the non-haven countries}}</ref> In addition, ''tax justice'' campaign groups have been equally critical of Hines, and others, in these views.<ref name="ns1"/><ref name="ns2"/> Research in June 2018 by the IMF showed that much of the [[foreign direct investment]] ("FDI") that came from tax havens into higher-tax countries, had really originated from the higher-tax country,<ref name="imfx"/> and for example, that the largest source of FDI into the United Kingdom, was actually from the United Kingdom, but invested via tax havens.<ref name="quartz">{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/1300880/tax-havens-mean-40-of-foreign-direct-investments-are-artificial/|title=How tax havens turn economic statistics into nonsense|date=11 June 2018|author=Max de Haldevang|publisher=[[Quartz (publication)]]|quote=For example, according to the UK Treasury, on the surface it looks like Britain’s second-biggest investor is the Netherlands. But the UK Treasury has admitted most of those investments actually consist of British cash that has been sent to Holland for tax purposes and rerouted back home. So, Britain’s second biggest foreign investor is itself.}}</ref>
The boundaries with wider contested economic theories on the effects of corporate taxation on economic growth, and whether there should be corporate taxes, are easy to blur. Other major academic leaders in tax haven research, such as [[Gabriel Zucman|Zucman]], highlight the injustice of tax havens and see the effects as lost income for the development of society.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/08/tax-havens-dodging-theft-multinationals-avoiding-tax|title=The desperate inequality behind global tax dodging|publisher=The Guardian|author=Gabriel Zucman|date=8 November 2017}}</ref> It remains a controversial area with advocates on both sides.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-07-25/fighting-corporate-tax-avoidance-can-kill-economic-growth|title=Fighting tax dodgers can kill economic growth|publisher=Bloomberg|date=25 July 2018}}</ref>
==Methodology==
{{cleanup section|date=September 2018|reason=list of structures seems out of date and not reflective of current structures}}
The way tax havens operate can be viewed in the following principal contexts:<ref name=Tolley>''Tolley's Offshore Service'' (2006), {{ISBN|1-4057-1568-5}}</ref>{{page needed|date=April 2016}}
===Personal residency===
Since the early 20th century, wealthy individuals from high-tax countries have sought to relocate themselves in low-tax countries. In most countries in the world, residence is the primary basis of taxation—see [[tax residence]]. The low-tax country chosen may levy no, or only very low, income tax and may not levy [[capital gains tax]], or [[inheritance tax]]. Individuals are normally unable to return to their previous higher-tax country for more than a few days a year without reverting their tax residence to their former country. They are sometimes referred to as [[tax exile]]s.<ref name=Tolley/>{{page needed|date=April 2016}}
===Corporate residency=== {{See also|Tax inversion}}
Corporations can establish subsidiary corporations and/or regional [[headquarters]] in corporate tax havens for tax planning purposes. Where a corporate moves their legal headquarters to a haven, it is known as a corporate tax inversion.<ref name="bbb">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/tax-inversion-tracker/|title=Tracking Tax Runaways|publisher=Bloomberg News|date=1 March 2017}}</ref><ref>Reuven S. Avi-Yonah (2002): For Haven's Sake: Reflections on Inversion Transactions; University of Michigan Law School, Tax Notes, Vol. 95 no. 12, 17 June 2002.</ref> The rise of [[intellectual property]], or IP, as a major [[Corporate haven#IP-Based BEPS tools|BEPS tax tool]], has meant that corporates can achieve much of the benefits of a tax inversion, without needing to move their headquarters. Apple's $300 billion quasi-inversion to Ireland in 2015 (see [[leprechaun economics]]) is a good example of this.
===Asset holding=== Asset holding involves utilizing an [[offshore trust]] or [[offshore company]], or a trust owning a company. The company or trust will be formed in one tax haven, and will usually be administered and resident in another. The function is to hold assets, which may consist of a portfolio of investments under management, trading companies or groups, physical assets such as [[real estate]] or valuable [[Personal property|chattels]]. The essence of such arrangements is that by changing the ownership of the assets into an entity which is not tax resident in the high-tax country, they cease to be taxable in that country.<ref name=Tolley/>{{page needed|date=April 2016}}
Often the mechanism is employed to avoid a specific tax. For example, a wealthy [[testator]] could transfer his house into an offshore company; he can then settle the shares of the company on trust (with himself being a trustee with another trustee, whilst holding the beneficial [[life estate]]) for himself for life, and then to his daughter. On his death, the shares will automatically vest in the daughter, who thereby acquires the house, without the house having to go through [[probate]] and being assessed with inheritance tax.<ref>This is a simplistic example; in most sophisticated tax codes there are extensive provisions for catching "gifts" (such as a [[Declaration (law)|declaration of trust]]) made for a specified time preceding death.</ref> Most countries assess inheritance tax, and all other taxes, on real estate within their jurisdiction, regardless of the nationality of the owner, so this would not work with a house in most countries. It is more likely to be done with intangible assets.<ref name=Tolley/>{{page needed|date=April 2016}}
===Trading and other business activity=== {{see also|Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Transfer mispricing}} Many businesses which do not require a specific geographical location or extensive labor are set up in a country to minimize tax exposure. Perhaps the best illustration of this is the number of [[reinsurance]] companies which have migrated to [[Law of Bermuda|Bermuda]] over the years. Other examples include internet-based services and group finance companies. In the 1970s and 1980s corporate groups were known to form offshore entities for the purposes of "reinvoicing". These reinvoicing companies simply made a margin without performing any economic function, but as the margin arose in a tax-free country, it allowed the group to "skim" profits from the high-tax country. Most sophisticated tax codes now prevent [[transfer pricing]] schemes of this nature.<ref name=Tolley/>{{page needed|date=April 2016}}
===Financial intermediaries=== Much of the economic activity in tax havens today consists of professional [[financial services]] such as [[mutual fund]]s, banking, [[life insurance]] and [[pension]]s. Generally, the funds are deposited with the intermediary in the low-tax country, and the intermediary then on-lends or invests the money in another location. Although such systems do not normally avoid tax in the principal customer's country, it enables financial service providers to provide international products without adding another layer of taxation. This has proved particularly successful in the area of [[offshore fund]]s. It has been estimated over 75% of the world's [[hedge fund]]s, probably the riskiest form of collective investment vehicle, are domiciled in the Cayman Islands, with nearly $1.1 trillion US [[Assets under management]]<ref>[http://www.dailyii.com/article.asp?ArticleID=1039798&LS=EMS73445 ''Institutional Investor''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310221113/http://www.dailyii.com/article.asp?ArticleID=1039798&LS=EMS73445 |date=10 March 2007 }}, 15 May 2006</ref> although statistics in the hedge fund industry are notoriously speculative.
=== Anonymity and bearer shares === [[Bearer share]]s allow for anonymous ownership, and thus have been criticized for facilitating [[money laundering]] and [[tax evasion]]; these shares are also available in some OECD countries as well as in the U.S. state of Wyoming.<ref>Gravelle JG. (2013). [https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R40623.pdf Tax Havens: International Tax Avoidance and Evasion]. CRS.</ref>{{Rp|7}} In a 2010 study in which the researcher attempted to set-up anonymous corporations found that 13 of the 17 attempts were successful in OECD countries, such as the United States and the United Kingdom, while only 4 of 28 attempts were successful in countries typically labeled tax havens.<ref>Sharman JC. (2010). [http://www.relooney.info/0_New_8887.pdf Shopping for Anonymous Shell Companies: An Audit Study of Anonymity and Crime in the International Financial System] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710115443/http://www.relooney.info/0_New_8887.pdf |date=10 July 2012 }}. ''Journal of Economic Perspectives''.</ref> The last two states in America permitting bearer shares, Nevada and Delaware made them illegal in 2007. In 2011, an OECD peer review recommended that the United Kingdom improve its bearer share laws.<ref>[http://www.taxjournal.com/tj/articles/bearer-shares-and-delays-blot-uk-record-information-exchange-32851 Bearer shares and delays blot UK record on information exchange]. ''Tax Journal''.</ref> The UK abolished the use of bearer shares in 2015.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
In 2012 the Guardian wrote that there are 28 persons as directors for 21,500 companies.<ref>HS 27.11.2012</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Leigh|first1=David|last2=Frayman|first2=Harold|last3=Ball|first3=James|title=Offshore secrets revealed: the shadowy side of a booming industry|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/nov/25/offshore-secrets-revealed-shadowy-side|website=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=25 November 2012|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref>
===Money and exchange control=== {{See also|Fixed exchange rate|Dollarization|Money laundering}}
Most tax havens have a double monetary control system, which distinguish residents from non-resident as well as foreign currency from the domestic, the local currency one. In general, residents are subject to monetary controls, but not non-residents. A company, belonging to a non-resident, when trading overseas is seen as non-resident in terms of exchange control. It is possible for a foreigner to create a company in a tax haven to trade internationally; the company’s operations will not be subject to exchange controls as long as it uses foreign currency to trade outside the tax haven. Tax havens usually have currency easily convertible or linked to an easily convertible currency. Most are convertible to [[US dollars]], [[euro]] or to [[pounds sterling]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
==Various developments==
=== U.S. Legislation === {{Main|Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act}} The [[Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act]] (FATCA) was passed by the US Congress to stop the outflow of money from the country into tax haven bank accounts. With the strong backing of the [[Obama administration|Obama Administration]], Congress drafted the FATCA legislation and added it into the [[Hiring Incentives to Restore Employment Act]] (HIRE) signed into law by President Obama in March 2010.
FATCA requires foreign financial institutions (FFI) of broad scope – banks, stock brokers, hedge funds, pension funds, insurance companies, trusts – to report directly to the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) all clients who are [[U.S. person]]s. Starting January 2014, FATCA requires FFIs to provide annual reports to the IRS on the name and address of each U.S. client, as well as the largest account balance in the year and total debits and credits of any account owned by a U.S. person.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/article/0,,id=242164,00.html | title=Treasury and IRS Issue Guidance Outlining Phased Implementation of FATCA Beginning in 2013 | author=[[U.S. Internal Revenue Service]] | date=2011-07-14 | accessdate=2011-08-25 }}</ref> If an institution does not comply, the U.S. will impose a 30% withholding tax on all its transactions concerning U.S. securities, including the proceeds of sale of securities.{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}}
In addition, FATCA requires any foreign company not listed on a stock exchange or any foreign partnership which has 10% U.S. ownership to report to the IRS the names and [[Taxpayer Identification Number|tax identification number]] (TIN) of any U.S. owner. FATCA also requires U.S. citizens and [[Permanent residence (United States)|green card holders]] who have foreign financial assets in excess of $50,000 to complete a new [[Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act|Form 8938]] to be filed with the [[IRS tax forms|1040 tax return]], starting with fiscal year 2010.<ref>"For most individual taxpayers, this means they will start filing Form 8938 with their 2011 income tax return to be filed this coming tax filing season."{{cite web | url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/corporations/article/0,,id=251217,00.html | title=Do I need to file Form 8938, "Statement of Specified Foreign Financial Assets"? | author=[[U.S. Internal Revenue Service]] | date=2012-01-25 | accessdate=2012-07-03 }}</ref> The delay is indicative of a controversy over the feasibility of implementing the legislation as evidenced in this paper from the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.piie.com/realtime/?p=2276| title=Gary Clyde Hufbauer: The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act: Imperial Overreach| date=2011-07-22 | accessdate=2011-08-25 }}</ref>
An unintended consequence of FATCA and its cost of compliance for non-US banks is that some non-US banks are refusing to serve American investors.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/0,1518,803742,00.html | title=European banks stop serving American customers | author=Spiegel Online | date={{date|2011-12-14}} | accessdate={{date|2011-12-31}} }}</ref> Concerns have also been expressed that, because FATCA operates by imposing [[withholding taxes]] on U.S. investments, this will drive foreign financial institutions (particularly [[hedge funds]]) away from investing in the U.S. and thereby reduce [[Market liquidity|liquidity]] and [[capital inflows]] into the US.<ref>"Another approach would involve some global funds avoiding American assets entirely. That can hardly be what Congress had in mind." {{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21540270|title=Scratched by the FATCA|author=[[The Economist]]|date=2011-11-26|accessdate=2012-07-16}}</ref> {{See also| Taxation of United States persons|Taxation of non-resident Americans}}
===Tax Justice Network Report 2012=== A 2012 report by the British [[Tax Justice Network]] estimated that between US$21 trillion and $32 trillion is sheltered from taxes in unreported tax havens worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-18944097|title=Tax havens: Super-rich 'hiding' at least $21tn|author=|date=|work=BBC News}}</ref> If such wealth earns 3% annually and such [[capital gains]] were taxed at 30%, it would generate between $190 billion and $280 billion in tax revenues, more than any other [[tax shelters|tax shelter]].<ref name=tjn12>Tax Justice Network (22 July 2012) [http://www.taxjustice.net/cms/upload/pdf/The_Price_of_Offshore_Revisited_Presser_120722.pdf "Revealed: Global super-rich has at least $21 trillion hidden in secret tax havens"]</ref> If such hidden offshore assets are considered, many countries with governments nominally in debt are shown to be net creditor nations.<ref name=cbc12>Canadian Broadcasting Co. (22 July 2012) [http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/07/22/tax-havens.html "Wealthy hiding $21 trillion in tax havens, report says"]</ref> However, despite being widely quoted, the methodology used in the calculations has been questioned,<ref name="Gordon & Morriss">{{cite journal |last=Gordon |first=Richard |last2=Morriss |first2=Andrew |date=20 October 2013 |title=Moving Money: International Financial Flows, Taxes & Money Laundering |ssrn=2348144 |journal=Hastings International and Comparative Law Review |publisher= |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages= |doi= |accessdate=}} "''such claims rest on poor data and analysis, and on mistakes about how financial transactions, international taxation, and anti-money laundering rules actually work''" (abstract)</ref> and the tax policy director of the [[Chartered Institute of Taxation]] also expressed skepticism over the accuracy of the figures.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">John Whiting, tax policy director at the [[Chartered Institute of Taxation]] commented "There clearly are some significant amounts hidden away, but if it really is that size what is being done with it all?" and "If the suggestion is that such amounts are actively hidden and never accessed, that seems odd—not least in terms of what the tax authorities are doing. In fact, the US, UK and German authorities are doing a lot", and noting that if the figures were accurate "you would expect the havens to be more conspicuously wealthy than they are". However, he also admitted that "I cannot disprove the figures at all, but they do seem staggering" {{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18944097|title=Tax havens: Super-rich 'hiding' at least $21tn|date=2012-07-22|accessdate=2012-10-03}}</ref> Another recent study estimated the amount of global offshore wealth at the smaller—but still sizable—figure of US$7.6 trillion. This estimate included financial assets only: "My method probably delivers a lower bound, in part because it only captures financial wealth and disregards real assets. After all, high-net-worth individuals can stash works of art, jewelry, and gold in 'freeports,' warehouses that serve as repositories for valuables—Geneva, Luxembourg, and Singapore all have them. High-net-worth individuals also own real estate in foreign countries."<ref name=Zucman>{{cite journal |author=[[Gabriel Zucman]] |title=Taxing across Borders: Tracking Personal Wealth and Corporate Profits |url=http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/jep.28.4.121 |journal=[[Journal of Economic Perspectives]]|volume=28 |issue=4 |pages=121–48 |doi= 10.1257/jep.28.4.121|accessdate=20 November 2014|date=August 2014}}</ref> A study of 60 large US companies found that they deposited $166 billion in offshore accounts during 2012, sheltering over 40% of their profits from U.S. taxes.<ref name=ThurmLinebaugh>{{cite news|title=More U.S. Profits Parked Abroad, Saving on Taxes|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324034804578348131432634740|accessdate=19 March 2013|newspaper=Wall Street Journals|date=March 10, 2013|author=Scott Thurm|author2=Kate Linebaugh}}</ref>
===Bank data leak 2013=== Details of thousands of owners of offshore companies were published in April 2013 in a joint collaboration between ''[[The Guardian]]'' and the [[International Consortium of Investigative Journalists]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/tax-haven-data-leak-names-names-raises-questions-172346691--finance.html|title=Tax haven data leak names names, raises questions|author=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=2013-04-05}}</ref> The data was later published on a publicly accessible website in an attempt to "[[Crowdsourcing|crowd-source]]" the data.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/jun/15/database-app-icij-tax-havens|title=Offshore Leaks app puts secret users of tax havens in the public eye|author=[[The Guardian]]|date=2013-06-15}}</ref> The publication of the list appeared to be timed to coincide with the [[39th G8 summit|2013 G8 summit]] chaired by British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] which emphasised tax evasion and transparency.
===Liechtenstein banking scandal=== {{Main|2008 Liechtenstein tax affair}} Germany announced in February 2008 that it had paid €4.2 million to {{Interlanguage link multi|Heinrich Kieber|de}},<ref>Mr Kieber seems to be an unlikely hero for law enforcement authorities. A convicted fraudster, reports indicate that after initially stealing the information, he [[blackmail]]ed the Liechtenstein authorities into reducing and dropping criminal charges against him relating to [[property fraud]] in Spain. However, before returning the disks he made copies which he later sold to foreign governments after he left the country. Further reports indicate that he now lives under a new name in Australia.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/liechtenstein-s-shadowy-informant-tax-whistleblower-sold-data-to-the-us-a-537640.html|title=Liechtenstein's Shadowy Informant: Tax Whistleblower Sold Data to the US|first=SPIEGEL|last=Staff|date=25 February 2008|publisher=|via=Spiegel Online}}</ref> a former data archivist of [[LGT Bank|LGT Treuhand]], a Liechtenstein bank, for a list of 1,250 customers of the bank and their accounts' details. Investigations and arrests followed relating to charges of illegal tax evasion. The German authorities shared the data with U.S. [[Revenue service|tax authorities]], but the British government paid a further £100,000 for the same data.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/mar/02/tax.personalfinancenews|title=A journey from haven to hell|author=Nick Mathiason|work=the Guardian|accessdate=29 July 2015}}</ref> Other governments, notably Denmark and Sweden, refused to pay for the information regarding it as stolen property.<ref>[[Denmark]]'s tax minister, [[Kristian Jensen]], said: "I think it's a moral problem to reward a criminal for some information that he stole... I don't like this and I don't think this ethic is the best way to ensure that taxes are paid correctly."</ref> The Liechtenstein authorities subsequently accused the German authorities of espionage.<ref>{{cite news|author=Harry de Quetteville 12:01AM GMT 20 Feb 2008 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2008/02/20/wliech120.xml |title=''The Daily Telegraph'', 26 February 2008 |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2008-02-20 |accessdate=2011-03-22 |location=London}}</ref>
However, regardless of whether unlawful tax evasion was being engaged in, the incident has fuelled the perception among European governments and the press that tax havens provide facilities [[Bank secrecy|shrouded in secrecy]] designed to facilitate unlawful tax evasion, rather than legitimate tax planning and legal tax mitigation schemes. This in turn has led to a call for "crackdowns" on tax havens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accountancyage.com/accountancyage/news/2210944/germany-call-tax-haven|title=Germany to call for tax haven crackdown|website=Accountancyage.com|accessdate=29 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704212338/http://www.accountancyage.com/accountancyage/news/2210944/germany-call-tax-haven|archive-date=4 July 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Whether the calls for such a crackdown are mere posturing or lead to more definitive activity by mainstream economies to restrict access to tax havens is yet to be seen. No definitive announcements or proposals have yet been made by the [[European Union]] or governments of the member states.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}}
===German legislation=== [[Peer Steinbrück]], the former German finance minister, announced in January 2009 a plan to amend fiscal laws. New regulations would disallow that payments to companies in certain countries that shield money from disclosure rules to be declared as operational expenses. The effect of this would make banking in such states unattractive and expensive.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.spiegel.de/wirtschaft/0,1518,601859,00.html | title=Steinbrück forciert Kampf gegen Steuerparadiese |author=[[Der Spiegel]] | date=2009-01-17 | accessdate=2009-01-17 | language=German}}</ref>
===UK Foot report=== In November 2009, Sir Michael Foot, a former Bank of England official and Bahamas bank inspector, delivered a report on the British [[Crown dependencies|Crown Dependencies]] and [[British Overseas Territories|Overseas Territories]] for [[HM Treasury]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/press_98_09.htm|title=Michael Foot publishes final report|publisher=[[HM Treasury]]|date=2009-10-29|accessdate=2009-11-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091118151755/http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/press_98_09.htm|archivedate=18 November 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The report indicated that while many of the territories "had a good story to tell", others needed to improve their abilities to detect and prevent financial crime. The report also stressed the view that narrow tax bases presented long term strategic risks and that the economies should seek to diversify and broaden their tax bases.<ref name="bvi.org.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.bvi.org.uk/government/pressrelease/michaelfootreview|title=Governor and Premier Welcome Michael Foot Review Conclusions|date=2009-10-30|accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>
It indicated that tax revenue lost by the UK government appeared to be much smaller than had previously been estimated (see above under [[Tax haven#Lost tax revenue|Lost tax revenue]]), and also stressed the importance of the liquidity provided by the territories to the United Kingdom. The Crown Dependencies and Overseas Territories broadly welcomed the report.<ref name="bvi.org.uk"/> The pressure group [[Tax Justice Network]], unhappy with the findings, commented that "[a] weak man, born to be an apologist, has delivered a weak report."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://taxjustice.blogspot.com/2009/10/foot-report.html|title=The Foot Report: a setback|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=2009-10-29|accessdate=2009-11-05}}</ref>
===G20 tax haven blacklist=== <!--- Commenting out this quote, as reference is dated 2008. It may be valid, but needs verification. [[User:Wwheaton|Wwheaton]] {{Quote box | quote = There is a building in the Cayman Islands that houses supposedly 12,000 US-based corporations. That's either the biggest building in the world or the biggest }} --> At the [[2009 G-20 London summit|London G20 summit]] on 2 April 2009, [[G20]] countries agreed to define a [[blacklist]] for tax havens, to be segmented according to a four-tier system, based on compliance with an "internationally agreed tax standard."<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/02/g20-summit-tax-havens|title = G20 declares door shut on tax havens|work =The Guardian|date = 2 April 2009|first1= Nicholas|last1= Watt|first2= Larry|last2= Elliott |first3= Julian|last3= Borger|first4= Ian|last4= Black}}</ref> The list as per 2 April 2009 can be viewed on the OECD website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/ctp/42497950.pdf |title=A Progress Report on The Jurisdictions Surveyed by The OECD Global Forum in Implementing The Internationally Agreed Tax Standard|date= 2009-04-02 |format=PDF |accessdate =|publisher = OECD}}</ref> The four tiers were:
# Those that have substantially implemented the standard (includes most countries but [[China]] still excludes [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]]). # Tax havens that have committed to – but not yet fully implemented – the standard (includes [[Montserrat]], [[Nauru]], [[Niue]], [[Panama]], and [[Vanuatu]]) # Financial centres that have committed to – but not yet fully implemented – the standard (includes [[Guatemala]], [[Costa Rica]] and [[Uruguay]]). # Those that have not committed to the standard (an empty category)
Those countries in the bottom tier were initially classified as being 'non-cooperative tax havens'. Uruguay was initially classified as being uncooperative. However, upon appeal the OECD stated that it did meet tax transparency rules and thus moved it up. The Philippines took steps to remove itself from the blacklist and [[Malaysian Prime Minister]] [[Najib Razak]] had suggested earlier that Malaysia should not be in the bottom tier.<ref>{{cite news |title=OECD names and shames tax havens |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-04-03 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7980848.stm |accessdate=2009-04-04}}</ref>
In April 2009 the OECD announced through its chief Angel Gurria that Costa Rica, Malaysia, the Philippines and Uruguay have been removed from the blacklist after they had made "a full commitment to exchange information to the OECD standards."<ref name="bbc2009-04-07">{{cite news |title=OECD removes tax havens from list |author=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7987417.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-04-07 |accessdate=2009-04-07 }}</ref> Despite calls from the former [[French President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] for [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]] to be included on the list separately from China, they are as yet not included independently, although it is expected that they will be added at a later date.<ref name="Guardian" />
Government response to the crackdown has been broadly supportive, although not universal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Save the tax havens – we need them |publisher=The Times |date=2009-04-12 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article6078115.ece |accessdate=2009-04-14 | location=London |first=Eamonn | last=Butler}}</ref> [[List of Prime Ministers of Luxembourg|Luxembourg Prime Minister]] [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] has criticised the list, stating that it has "no credibility", for failing to include various states of the USA which provide incorporation infrastructure which are indistinguishable from the aspects of pure tax havens to which the G20 object.<ref>{{cite news |title=Welcome to tax-dodge city, USA |publisher=The Guardian |date=2009-04-10|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/apr/10/tax-havens-blacklist-us-delaware |accessdate=2009-04-14 | location=London | first=Andrew | last=Clark}}</ref> As of 2012, 89 countries have implemented reforms sufficient to be listed on the OECD's white list.<ref>[http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/07/26/tax-offshore-idINDEE86P04L20120726 "Tax haven clampdown yields cash but secrecy still thrives."] ''Reuters'', 26 July 2012.</ref> According to [[Transparency International]] half of the least corrupted countries were tax havens<!--, and TI is criticized of it-->.<ref>[http://fifi.voima.fi/voima-artikkeli/2013/numero-3/transparency-hyvat-veljet-kahvilla Transparency – Hyvät veljet kahvilla] Voima April 2013</ref>
===EU tax haven blacklist=== In December 2017, European Union adopted blacklist of tax havens in a bid to discourage the most aggressive tax dodging practices. It also had a so-called gray list which includes those who have committed to change their rules on tax transparency and cooperation. The 17 blacklisted territories are: [[American Samoa]], [[Bahrain]], [[Barbados]], [[Grenada]], [[Guam]], [[South Korea]], [[Macau]], [[The Marshall Islands]], [[Mongolia]], [[Namibia]], [[Palau]], [[Panama]], [[Saint Lucia]], [[Samoa]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Tunisia]], [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-blacklist/eu-tax-haven-blacklist-set-to-shrink-further-causing-outcry-idUSKCN1GI1F4|title=EU tax haven blacklist set to shrink further, causing outcry|first=Francesco|last=Guarascio|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Some activists denounced the listing process as a whitewash and had called for the inclusion in the blacklist of some EU countries accused of facilitating tax avoidance, like [[Luxembourg]], [[Malta]], [[Ireland]] and the [[Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-42237315|title=First tax havens blacklist published by EU|first=Jamie|last=Robertson|date=5 December 2017|accessdate=17 April 2018|website=Bbc.com}}</ref>
===Common Reporting Standard (CRS)=== The [[Common Reporting Standard]] is an information standard for the automatic exchange of tax and financial information on a global level developed by the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] in 2014. Participating in the CRS from 1 January 2017 onwards are Australia, the Bahamas, Bahrain, Brazil, Brunei Darussalam, Canada, Chile, China, The Cook Islands, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Israel, Japan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Macau, Malaysia, Mauritius, Monaco, New Zealand, Panama, Qatar, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Switzerland, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/automatic-exchange/common-reporting-standard/|title=Common Reporting Standard (CRS) – Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|website=Oecd.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
==History==
The use of differing tax laws between two or more countries to try to mitigate tax liability is probably as old as taxation itself.<ref name="ronen.palan"/>In [[Ancient Greece]], some of the [[Greek Islands]] were used as depositories by the sea traders of the era to place their foreign goods to thus avoid the two-percent tax imposed by the [[city-state]] of [[Athens]] on imported goods. The practice may have first reached prominence through the avoidance of the [[Cinque Ports#Formation and privileges|Cinque Ports]] and later the [[staple port]]s in the twelfth and fourteenth centuries respectively. In 1721, [[United States|American]] colonies traded from [[Latin America]] to avoid [[British Empire|British]] taxes.{{citation needed||date=April 2016}}
Various countries claim to be the oldest tax haven in the world. For example, the [[Channel Islands]] claim their tax independence dating as far back as [[Norman Conquest]], while the [[Isle of Man]] claims to trace its fiscal independence to even earlier times. Nonetheless, the modern concept of a tax haven is generally accepted to have emerged at an uncertain point in the immediate aftermath of [[World War I]].<ref>"[T]he tax haven is a creature of the twentieth century, and began to be used extensively because of the high levels of tax which prevailed after the First World War" at para 26.1, ''Tolley's International Tax Planning'' (2002), {{ISBN|0-7545-1339-4}}</ref> [[Bermuda]] sometimes optimistically claims to have been the first tax haven based upon the creation of the first [[offshore company|offshore companies]] legislation in 1935 by the newly created law firm of [[Conyers Dill & Pearman]].<ref>See generally Introduction to ''Tolley's International Initiatives Affecting Financial Havens'' (2001), {{ISBN|0-406-94264-1}}</ref> However, the Bermudian claim is debatable when compared against the enactment of a [[Trust law|Trust Law]] by [[Liechtenstein]] in 1926 to attract offshore capital.<ref>The ''Personen- und Gesellschaftsrecht'' of 20 January 1926</ref>{{nonspecific|date=April 2016}}
Most economic commentators suggest that the first "true" tax haven was [[Switzerland]], followed closely by Liechtenstein.<ref name=Tolley/>{{page needed|date=April 2016}} [[Banking in Switzerland|Swiss banks]] had long been a ''capital haven'' for people fleeing social upheaval in Russia, Germany, South America and elsewhere. However, in the early part of the twentieth century, during the years immediately following [[World War I]], many European governments raised taxes sharply to help pay for reconstruction efforts following the devastation of World War I. By and large, Switzerland, having remained neutral during the Great War, avoided these additional infrastructure costs and was consequently able to maintain a low level of taxes. As a result, there was a considerable influx of capital into the country for tax related reasons. It is difficult, nonetheless, to pinpoint a single event or precise date which clearly identifies the emergence of the modern tax haven.{{citation needed||date=April 2016}}
The use of modern tax havens has gone through several phases of development subsequent to the [[interwar period]]. From the 1920s to the 1950s, tax havens were usually referenced as the avoidance of personal taxation. The terminology was often used with reference to countries to which a person could retire and mitigate their post retirement tax position, a usage which was still being echoed to some degree in a 1990 report, which included indications of [[quality of life]] in various tax havens which future [[tax exile]]s may wish to consider.<ref>''Tax Havens and Their Uses'', [[The Economist]],1990, Special Report No. 1191, {{ISBN|0 85058 292 X}}.</ref>
From the 1950s onward, there was significant growth in the use of tax havens by corporate groups to mitigate their global [[Tax incidence|tax burden]]. The strategy generally relied upon there being a [[double taxation]] [[tax treaty|treaty]] between a large country with a high tax burden (that the company would otherwise be subject to), and a smaller country with a low tax burden. By structuring the group ownership through the smaller country, corporations could take advantage of the double taxation treaty, paying taxes at the much lower rate. Although some of these double tax treaties survive,{{when|date=April 2016}}, for example between [[Barbados]] and [[Japan]], between [[Cyprus]] and [[Russia]] and [[Mauritius]] with [[India]], which India sought to renegotiate in 2007,<ref>Sidhartha [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/NEWS/India_Business/India_to_push_for_change_in_tax_treaty_with_Mauritius/articleshow/1068539.cms India to push for change in tax treaty with Mauritius], Times of India, 6 January 2007,</ref> most major countries began repealing their double taxation treaties with [[Microstate|micro-states]] in the 1970s, to prevent [[corporate tax]] leakage in this manner.{{citation needed||date=April 2016}}
In the early to mid-1980s, most tax havens changed the focus of their legislation to create corporate vehicles which were "[[ring fence|ring-fenced]]" and exempt from local taxation (although they usually could not trade locally either). These vehicles were usually called "exempt companies" or "[[international business corporation]]s". However, in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the [[OECD]] began a series of initiatives aimed at tax havens to curb the abuse of what the OECD referred to as "[[unfair tax competition]]". Under pressure from the OECD, most major tax havens repealed their laws permitting these ring-fenced vehicles to be incorporated, but concurrently they amended their tax laws so that a company which did not actually trade within the country would not accrue any local tax liability.<ref>For example, the [[British Virgin Islands]] repealed the [[International Business Companies Act]] (Cap 291) (which had prohibited such companies from trading locally) and enacted the [[BVI Business Companies Act]] 2004 (which permitted this) in its place. Contemporaneously it varied its [[Taxation in the British Virgin Islands|tax laws]] by amending the Income Tax Act (Cap 206), which amended the rate of income tax for individuals and corporations to zero, along with the Payroll Taxes Act 2004 which imposed a (new) payroll tax on person employed by businesses within the British Virgin Islands.</ref>

page.title: The Helsinki Rules on the Uses of the Waters of International Rivers

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
'''The Helsinki Rules on the Uses of the Waters of International Rivers''' is an international guideline regulating how rivers and their connected [[groundwater]]s that cross national boundaries may be used, adopted by the [[International Law Association]] (ILA) in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] in August 1966. In spite of its adoption by the ILA, there is no mechanism in place that enforces the rules.<ref>{{cite news | last = Browne | first = Anthony | date = 2003-08-19 | title = Water wars, water wars, everywhere... | publisher = The Times | url = http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/article877529.ece | accessdate = 2009-02-12}}</ref> Notwithstanding the guideline's lack of formal status, its work on rules governing international rivers was pioneering.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Raj | first1 = Krishna |last2 = Salman | first2 = Salman M.A. | chapter = International Groundwater Law and the World Bank Policy for Projects on Transboundary Groundwater | editor1-last = Salman | editor1-first = Salman M. A. | title = Groundwater: Legal and Policy Perspectives : Proceedings of a World Bank Seminar | publisher= World Bank Publications | year = 1999 | isbn = 0-8213-4613-X | pages = 171–172}}</ref> It led to the creation of the [[United Nations]]' [[Convention on the Law of Non-Navigational Uses of International Watercourses]]. In 2004, it was superseded by the [[Berlin Rules on Water Resources]].
==Provisions== Applicable to all [[drainage basin]]s that cross national boundaries, except where other agreement between bordering nations exists, the Helsinki Rules assert the rights of all bordering nations to an equitable share in the [[water resources]], with reasonable consideration of such factors as past customary usages of the resource and balancing variant needs and demands of the bordering nations. It also mandates protection of the resource by bordering nations with respect to [[water pollution]] in Chapter 3 (Articles IX to XI) and sets forth recommendations for resolving disputes over usage of such watercourses.
The Helsinki rules consist of 37 articles spread over 6 chapters.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://webworld.unesco.org/water/wwap/pccp/cd/pdf/educational_tools/course_modules/reference_documents/internationalregionconventions/helsinkirules.pdf |title= The Helsinki Rules on the Uses of the Waters of International Rivers |accessdate= 5 December 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070625012949/http://webworld.unesco.org/water/wwap/pccp/cd/pdf/educational_tools/course_modules/reference_documents/internationalregionconventions/helsinkirules.pdf |archivedate= 25 June 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Chapter 2, Article 4 states: "Each basin State is entitled, within its territory, to a reasonable and equitable share in the beneficial uses of the waters of an international drainage basin".
In determining what is reasonable and equitable share, all relevant factors are to be considered together and a conclusion reached on the basis of the whole. The list provided in Article 5 (2) is produced in full below:
1. The geography of the basin, including in particular the extent of the drainage area in the territory of each basin State
2. The hydrology of the basin, including in particular the contribution of water by each basin State
3. The climate affecting the basin
4. The past utilization of the waters of the basin, including in particular existing utilization
5. The economic and social needs of each basin State
6. The population dependent on the waters of the basin in each basin State
7. The comparative costs of alternative means of satisfying the economic and social needs of each basin State
8. The availability of other resources
9. The avoidance of unnecessary waste in the utilization of waters of the basin
10. The practicability of compensation to one or more of the co-basin States as a means of adjusting conflicts among uses
11. The degree to which the needs of a basin State may be satisfied, without causing substantial injury to a co-basin State
Article 6 precludes inherent preference of any use over others. Article 7 prohibits denial of reasonable use to a basin state on the basis of future uses of other states.
Article 8 relates to "existing reasonable uses".
Section 8 (1) states: "An existing reasonable use may continue in operation unless the factors justifying its continuance are outweighed by other factors leading to the conclusion that it be modified or terminated so as to accommodate a competing incompatible use".
Section 8 (2) defines the entry & exit criterion of an existing use.
Section 8 (3) prohibits a use that is incompatible with an already existing reasonable use at the time of becoming operational from being treated as an existing use.
==Limitations== Although "an important set of draft rules," according to Stephen McCaffrey of the [[McGeorge School of Law]], the Helsinki Rules do not address independent [[aquifer]]s, but only those connected to a river.<ref name=McCaffrey>{{cite book | last = McCaffrey | first = Stephen M. | chapter = International Groundwater Law: Evolution and Context | editor1-last = Salman | editor1-first = Salman M. A. | title = Groundwater: Legal and Policy Perspectives : Proceedings of a World Bank Seminar | publisher= World Bank Publications | year = 1999 | isbn = 0-8213-4613-X | page = 152}}</ref> Accordingly, the United Nations decided in 1970 to create a more inclusive set of guidelines, which after more than twenty years of investigation by the [[International Law Commission]] resulted in the adopting of the [[Convention on the Law of Non-Navigational Uses of International Watercourses]] in 1997.<ref name=Dellapenna>{{cite web|url=http://www.ualg.pt/5cigpa/comunicacoes/Berlin%20Rules%20Summary.doc |first=Joseph W. |last=Dellapenna |title=The Berlin rules on water resources: the new paradigm for international water law |publisher=[[Universidade do Algarve]] |accessdate=2009-02-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20080301203852/http://www.ualg.pt/5cigpa/comunicacoes/Berlin%20Rules%20Summary.doc |archivedate=March 1, 2008 }}</ref> The ILA itself addressed this limitation in adopting the [[Rules on International Groundwaters]], also known as the Seoul Rules, in [[Seoul, Korea]] in 1986 and the Berlin Rules on Water Resources in 2004, which superseded this guideline.<ref name=McCaffrey/><ref name=Dellapenna/>

{{Infobox person | name = Thomas Schirrmacher | image = Selfie am 82 Geburstag des Papstes 17 12 2017.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Thomas Schirrmacher and [[Pope Francis]] on his 82th birthday (2017-12-17) | other_names = Širmacher, Tomas (lit); Širmacheris, Tomas (lit); Širrmahers, Tomass (lit)<ref name="dnb">{{cite web | url = https://portal.d-nb.de/resolver.htm?referrerResultId=Thomas+Schirrmacher%26any&referrerPosition=12&identifier=123883717 | title = Katalog der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek | date = 2011-02-21 | publisher = D-NB | location = DE | language = de | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5wf8TH8I4?url=https://portal.d-nb.de/resolver.htm?referrerResultId=Thomas+Schirrmacher&any&referrerPosition=12&identifier=123883717 | archivedate = 2011-02-21 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> | birth_date = June 25th, 1960 | birth_place = [[Schwelm]] in [[Germany]] | nationality = [[Germany|German]] | citizenship = German | residence = [[Bonn]] in Germany<ref>{{cite web |url= http://cb.oxfordjournals.org/content/9/2-3/227.short | title = Medical Killing – An Evangelical Perspectiv | publisher=Swets & Zeitlinger | work = [[Oxford Journals]]}}</ref> | employer = [[Martin Bucer European Theological Seminary and Research Institutes]] | known_for = Christian moral philosophy, [[human rights]], [[religious freedom]] | spouse = [[Christine Schirrmacher]] | children =}} '''Thomas Schirrmacher''' is a Christian moral philosopher and a specialist in the [[Sociology of Religion]] and [[Religious freedom]]. He is known as a global [[human rights]] activist and holds a chair in Theology ([[Ethics]], [[Missiology]], World Religions).
Prof. Dr. theol. Dr. phil. Thomas Schirrmacher, PhD, ThD, DD, serves the [[World Evangelical Alliance]] as Associate Secretary General for Theological Concerns (responsible for Theology, Intrafaith Relations, Inter-faith Religious Freedom) and as Chair of the [[World Evangelical Alliance Theological Commission|Theological Commission]]. Since 2014 he is president of the [[International Society for Human Rights]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ishr.org/about-us/ishr-at-a-glance/ |title = ISHR – At a glance | publisher = International Society for Human Rights}}.</ref>
== Biography == === Family === Thomas Schirrmacher was born on June 25, 1960<ref>{{Citation | title = Who is Who in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland | issue = 6 | year = 1999 | place = Wien}}.</ref> to the german professor of [[Telecommunications engineering]] [[Bernd Schirrmacher]] and his wife Ingeborg. His great-grandfather was the historian [[Friedrich Wilhelm Schirrmacher]]. Thomas Schirrmacher is married to [[Christine Schirrmacher]] who is professor of Islamic Studies in Bonn, Germany.
=== Education === Thomas Schirrmacher studied theology from 1978 to 1982 at STH [[Basel]] ([[Switzerland]]) and since 1983 [[Cultural Anthropology]] and [[Comparative Religion]] at [[University of Bonn]]. He earned a Drs. theol. in Missiology and [[Ecumenism]] at [[Theological University of the Reformed Churches|Theological University]] ([[Kampen, Overijssel|Kampen]]/[[Netherlands]]) in 1984, and a Dr. theol. in Missiology and Ecumenics at [[Theological University of the Reformed Churches]] (Kampen/Netherlands) in 1985, a Ph.D. in [[Cultural Anthropology]] at [[Pacific Western University]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://en.scientificcommons.org/31676901 | language = de | title = Publikationsansicht: "Der göttliche Volkstumsbegriff" und der "Glaube an Deutschlands Grösse und heilige Sendung": Hans Naumann als Volkskundler und Germanist im Nationalsozialismus; eine Materialsammlung mit Daten zur Geschichte der Volkskunde an den Universitäten Bonn und Köln | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121023023744/http://en.scientificcommons.org/31676901 | archivedate = 2012-10-23 |year = 2000 |work= magazine.One UG |location= Berlin |publisher= Scientific commons}}.</ref> (today: [[California Miramar University]]) in Los Angeles (CA) in 1989, a Th.D. in [[Ethics]] at [[Whitefield Theological Seminary]] in Lakeland (FL) in 1996, and a Dr. phil. in [[Comparative Religion]] and [[Sociology of Religion]] at University of Bonn in 2007. In 1997 he got honorary doctorates (D.D.) from [[Cranmer Theological House]] and in 2006 from [[ACTS Academy of Higher Education | Acts University]] in [[Bangalore]].
=== Career === [[File:Schirrmacher at the President of Albania 2015.jpg|thumb|Schirrmacher at the President of Albania 2015]] Between 1982 and 1986 Schirrmacher was pastor of several church communities in Bonn. Since 1996 he is the president of the [[Martin Bucer European Theological Seminary and Research Institutes]], a theological seminary seated in [[Bonn]], [[Germany]] with campuses in several countries.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.bucer.de/mitarbeiter/ts.html |title = Dr. Schirrmacht at bucer.de | publisher = Martin Bucer Seminary}}</ref> From 1994 to 1998 Schirrmacher was professor of missions at the Philadelphia Theological Seminary and since 1995 he is professor for systematic theology at the [[Whitefield Theological Seminary]].<ref>[https://seminary.reformed.info/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Administrative-Bulletin.pdf Administrative Bulletin] of Whitefield Theological Seminary</ref> He is professor of the sociology of religion at the [[West University of Timişoara]].<ref>Thomas Schirrmacher at [https://uvt-ro.academia.edu/ThomasSchirrmacher Academia.edu].</ref>
Schirrmacher is chairman of the Board of Trustees of the ''Gebende Hände'' gGmbH (German: ''Giving Hands'' charitable [[Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung]]), an internationally active relief organisation.<ref>Thomas Schirrmacher at [https://www.gebende-haende.de/tschirrmacher.html Gebende Hände].</ref> He is member of the commission for religious freedom of the World Evangelical Alliance and since 2008 president of the International Institute for Religious Freedom (Bonn, Brussels/Geneva, Cape Town, Colombo, Brasília).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://iirf.eu/about-us/organisation/th-schirrmacher-germany/ |title = Dr. Schirrmacht at iirf.eu | publisher = International Institute for Religious Freedom}}</ref> He also is their speaker for human rights.<ref>An example of his lectures: [http://wrfnet.org/resources/2011/01/statement-concern-about-muslim-states-actions-regarding-religious-freedom Statement concern about muslim states actions regarding Religious Freedom].</ref> According to media he is one of the leading experts on the topic of [[persecution of christians]].<ref>So he is for example mentioned by the BBC concerning the question [https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-24864587 "Are there really 100,000 new Christian martyrs every year?“]. In 2013 he was involved in a documentary on the Persecution of Christian of the second german TV-Channel ZDF: [https://www.zdf.de/dokumentation/dokumentation/gefaehrlicher-glaube-100.html Gefährlicher Glaube]. See also on this topic Schirrmachers book: [http://www.worldevangelicals.org/resources/rfiles/res3_286_link_1307054270.pdf The Persecution of Christians Concerns Us All].</ref> Several times he was speaking as expert on human rights in the German Parliament.<ref>[https://www.cducsu.de/veranstaltungen/referenten/prof-dr-thomas-schirrmacher Events of Thomas Schirrmacher in the German Parliament].</ref> In October 2015 he was the only evangelical member of the catholic synod on family lead by [[Pope Francis]].<ref>Schirrmachers reports of the Synod were published by Christianity Today: [http://www.christianpost.com/author/thomas-schirrmacher/ Inside the Vatican Synod on Family]. Another interview on the Synod with Thomas Schirrmacher was published on [http://www.romereports.com/2015/10/18/synod-on-the-family-protestant-taking-part Rome Reports].</ref> He is president of the [[International Society for Human Rights]],<ref>[http://www.ishr.org/about-us/ishr-at-a-glance/ ISHR at a glance].</ref> manager of the Religious Liberty Commission of the German and the Swiss Evangelical Alliance, and director of the International Institute for Religious Freedom with regional offices for most continents: Brasilia (Latin America), Brussels/Bonn (Europe), Cape Town (Africa), Colombo and Dehlki (Asia), which cooperates with the UN Special Rapporteur for Freedom of Religion or Belief<ref>[https://iirf.eu/journal-books/religious-freedom-series/freedom-of-religion-or-belief/ Freedom of Religion or Belief]</ref>.
Another main focus of the work of Schirrmacher besides religious freedom in the area of human rights is the fight against [[Human trafficking]].
He speaks with church leaders like [[Pope Benedict XVI]],<ref>[http://www.worldea.org/news/4182/the-pope’s-resignation-did-not-come-as-such-a-great-surprise-an-interview-with-thomas-schirrmacher The Pope’s Resignation Did Not Come as Such a Great Surprise] - An Interview with Thomas Schirrmacher.</ref> [[Pope Francis]],<ref>[http://www.europeanea.org/index.php/schirrmacher-debating-catholic-leaders-with-a-bible-in-your-hand-is-much-easier-nowadays/ Schirrmacher: ‘Debating Catholic leaders with a Bible in your hand is much easier nowadays’].</ref> and the Ecumenical [[Patriarch Bartholomew]] I and gives lectures all around the world. He is also consultant of the [[Faith and Order Commission]], the Theological Commission of the [[World Council of Churches]], Chair of the Board of Advisors of the Central Council of Oriental Christians in Germany (ZOCD)<ref>[https://zocd.de/organe Zentralrat Orientalischer Christen in Deutschland]</ref>, and Member of the International Committee of the Global Christian Forum<ref>[http://www.globalchristianforum.org/docs/2015.01%20GCF%20News%20EN.pdf Global Christian Forum News]</ref>.
He has authored and edited more than 90 books, which have been translated into 17 languages.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thomasschirrmacher.net/bio/books-published/ |title = Books published by Dr Schirrmacher | publisher = Thomas Schirrmacher}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?query=thomas+schirrmacher&method=simpleSearch&cqlMode=true |title = Thmomas Schirrmacher im Katalog der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek | publisher = DNB}}</ref>
=== Honours === Schirrmacher received the following honours:
* Magister Praetor [[Order of merit]] for achievements relating to the planning of a civic central council of Christians in the Near East and Middle East (Oriental Christian Council) and for promoting the House of Ghassan, specifically noting “that he [enabled] the House’s personal contact to Pope Francis and to the Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew”<ref>Bonn Profiles – Press Reports: [https://www.bucer.de/ressource/details/bonner-querschnitte-382016-ausgabe-433-eng.html Thomas Schirrmacher receives the Order of Merit from the Royal House of Ghassan for his Activities relating to Human Rights in the Middle East]</ref> * [[Knight Grand Cross]] the highest order of the knightly order “The Sacred Order of Michael Archangel” for his efforts in the cause of human rights and religious freedom in the Near and Middle East<ref>Thomas Schirrmacher listet at the [http://www.michaelarchangel.org/officers.html Officers of Sacred Order of Saint Michael Archangel]</ref>
